There were 515,348 blank and invalidated ballots counted alongside the
1,363,854 ballots which indicated a choice for one of the non-territorial
alternatives. Under Puerto Rico Law, these ballots are not considered cast
votes and are therefore not reflected in the final tally.[133]  
  
On July 15, 2009, the [United Nations Special Committee on
Decolonization](/wiki/Special_Committee_on_Decolonization "Special Committee
on Decolonization") approved a draft resolution calling on the Government of
the United States to expedite a process that would allow the Puerto Rican
people to exercise fully their inalienable right to self-determination and
independence.[134]

On April 29, 2010, the U.S. House voted 223–169 to approve a measure for a
federally sanctioned process for Puerto Rico's self-determination, allowing
Puerto Rico to set a new referendum on whether to continue its present form of
commonwealth, or to have a different political status. If Puerto Ricans voted
to continue as a commonwealth, the Government of Puerto Rico was authorized to
conduct additional plebiscites at intervals of every eight years from the date
on which the results of the prior plebiscite were certified; if Puerto Ricans
voted to have a different political status, a second referendum would
determine whether Puerto Rico would become a U.S. state, an independent
country, or a sovereign nation associated with the U.S. that would not be
subject to the [Territorial Clause](/wiki/Territorial_Clause "Territorial
Clause") of the United States Constitution.[135] During the House debate, a
fourth option, to retain its present form of commonwealth (sometimes referred
to as "the [status quo](/wiki/Status_quo "Status quo")") political status, was
added as an option in the second plebiscite.[135][136]

Immediately following [U.S.
House](/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives "United States House of
Representatives") passage, H.R. 2499 was sent to the [U.S.
Senate](/wiki/United_States_Senate "United States Senate"), where it was given
two formal readings and referred to the [Senate Committee on Energy and
Natural
Resources](/wiki/United_States_Senate_Committee_on_Energy_and_Natural_Resources
"United States Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources"). On December
22, 2010, the 111th United States Congress adjourned without any Senate vote
on H.R.2499, killing the bill.[137]

The latest Task Force report was released on March 11, 2011. The report
suggested a two-plebiscite process, including a "first plebiscite that
requires the people of Puerto Rico to choose whether they wish to be part of
the United States (either via Statehood or Commonwealth) or wish to be
independent (via Independence or Free Association). If continuing to be part
of the United States were chosen in the first plebiscite, a second vote would
be taken between Statehood and Commonwealth."[138]

On June 14, 2011, President [Barack Obama](/wiki/Barack_Obama "Barack Obama")
"promised to support 'a clear decision' by the people of Puerto Rico on
statehood".[139] That same month, the United Nations Special Committee on
Decolonization passed a resolution and adopted a consensus text introduced by
Cuba's delegate on June 20, 2011, calling on the United States to expedite a
process "that would allow Puerto Ricans to fully exercise their inalienable
right to self-determination and independence".[132]

On November 6, 2012, a two-question referendum took place, simultaneous with
the general elections.[140][140][141] The first question asked voters whether
they wanted to maintain the current status under the territorial clause of the
U.S. Constitution. The second question posed three alternate status options if
the first question was approved: statehood, independence or [free
association](/wiki/Compact_of_Free_Association "Compact of Free
Association").[142] For the first question, 54 percent voted against the
current Commonwealth status. For the second question, 61.16% voted for
statehood, 33.34% for a sovereign free associated state, and 5.49% for
independence.[143]

There were also 515,348 blank and invalidated ballots, which are not reflected
in the final tally, as they are not considered cast votes under Puerto Rico
law.[133] On December 11, 2012, Puerto Rico's Legislature passed a concurrent
resolution to request to the President and the U.S. Congress action on
November 6, 2012 plebiscite results.[144] But on April 10, 2013, with the
issue still being widely debated, the White House announced that it will seek
$2.5 million to hold another referendum, this next one being the first Puerto
Rican status referendum to be financed by the [U.S. Federal
government](/wiki/Federal_government_of_the_United_States "Federal government
of the United States").[145]

In December 2015, the U.S. Government submitted a brief as [Amicus
Curiae](/wiki/Amicus_Curiae "Amicus Curiae") to the [U.S. Supreme
Court](/wiki/U.S._Supreme_Court "U.S. Supreme Court") related to the case
Commonwealth of Puerto Rico v. Sanchez Valle. The U.S. Government official
position is that the U.S. Constitution does not contemplate "sovereign
territories". That the Court has consistently recognized that "there is no
sovereignty in a Territory of the United States but that of the United States
itself". and a U.S. territory has "no independent sovereignty comparable to
that of a state. That is because "the Government of a territory owes its
existence wholly to the United States". Congress's plenary authority over
federal territories includes the authority to permit self-government, whereby
local officials administer a territory's internal affairs.[146]

On June 9, 2016, in Commonwealth of Puerto Rico vs Sanchez Valle, a 6–2
majority of the [Supreme Court of the United
States](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States "Supreme Court of the United
States") determined that Puerto Rico is a territory and lacks
Sovereignty.[146]

On June 30, 2016, the [President of the United States of
America](/wiki/President_of_the_United_States_of_America "President of the
United States of America") signed a new law approved by [U.S.
Congress](/wiki/U.S._Congress "U.S. Congress"), H.R. 5278: PROMESA,
establishing a Control Board over the Puerto Rico Government. This board will
have a significant degree of federal control involved in its establishment and
operations. In particular, the authority to establish the control board
derives from the federal government's constitutional power to "make all
needful rules and regulations" regarding U.S. territories; The President would
appoint all seven voting members of the board; and the board would have broad
sovereign powers to effectively overrule decisions by Puerto Rico's
legislature, governor, and other public authorities.[147]

### Political status

The latest referendum on statehood, independence, or an associated republic
was held on November 6, 2012. The people of Puerto Rico made history by
requesting, for the first time ever, the conclusion of the island's current
territorial status. Almost 78% of registered voters participated in a
plebiscite held to resolve Puerto Rico's status, and a slim but clear majority
(54%) disagreed with Puerto Rico maintaining its present territorial status.
Furthermore, among the possible alternatives, sixty-one percent (61%) of
voters chose the statehood option, while one third of the ballots were
submitted blank.[148][149]

On December 11, 2012, the [Legislative Assembly of Puerto
Rico](/wiki/Legislative_Assembly_of_Puerto_Rico "Legislative Assembly of
Puerto Rico") enacted a [concurrent resolution](/wiki/Concurrent_resolution
"Concurrent resolution") requesting the
[President](/wiki/President_of_the_United_States "President of the United
States") and the [Congress of the United
States](/wiki/Congress_of_the_United_States "Congress of the United States")
to respond to the referendum of the people of Puerto Rico, held on November 6,
2012, to end its current form of territorial status and to begin the process
to admit Puerto Rico as a State.[108] The initiative has not made Puerto Rico
into a state.

### Hurricane Maria

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Buildings_damaged_%2823538370818%29.jpg/300px-
Buildings_damaged_%2823538370818%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Buildings_damaged_\(23538370818\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Buildings_damaged_\(23538370818\).jpg "Enlarge")

A neighborhood in Puerto Rico heavily damaged by the storm.

In late September 2017, [Hurricane Maria](/wiki/Hurricane_Maria "Hurricane
Maria") hit the island as a Category 4 storm causing severe damage to homes,
other buildings and infrastructure. The recovery as of late November was slow
but progress had been made. Electricity was restored to two-thirds of the
island, although there was some doubt as to the number of residents getting
reliable power.[150] In January 2018, it was reported that close to 40 percent
of the island's customers still did not have electricity.[151] The vast
majority had access to water but were still required to boil it. The number
still living in shelters had dropped to 982 with thousands of others living
with relatives.[152] The official death toll at the time was 58 but some
sources indicated that the actual number is much higher.[150] A dam on the
island was close to failure and officials were concerned about additional
flooding from this source.[153]

Thousands had left Puerto Rico, with close to 200,000 having arrived in
Florida alone.[35] Those who were then living on the mainland experienced
difficulty in getting health care benefits.[154][155] A _[The New York
Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York Times")_ report on November 27
said it was understandable that Puerto Ricans wanted to leave the island.
"Basic essentials are hard to find and electricity and other utilities are
unreliable or entirely inaccessible. Much of the population has been unable to
return to jobs or to school and access to health care has been severely
limited." The Center for Puerto Rican Studies at New York's [Hunter
College](/wiki/Hunter_College "Hunter College") estimated that some half
million people, about 14% of the population, may permanently leave by
2019.[156]

The total damage on the island was estimated as up to $95 billion.[157] By the
end of November, FEMA had received over a million applications for aid and had
approved about a quarter of those. The US government had agreed in October to
provide funding to rebuild and up to $4.9 billion in loans to help the
island's government. FEMA had $464 million earmarked to help local governments
rebuild public buildings and infrastructure. Bills for other funding were
being considered in Washington but little progress had been made on those.[35]

A November 28, 2017 report by the [Sierra Club](/wiki/Sierra_Club "Sierra
Club") included this comment: "It will take years to rebuild Puerto Rico, not
just from the worst hurricane to make landfall since 1932, but to sustainably
overcome environmental injustices which made Maria's devastation even more
catastrophic".[153]

In May, 2017, the [Natural Resources Defense
Council](/wiki/Natural_Resources_Defense_Council "Natural Resources Defense
Council") reported that Puerto Rico's water system was the worst as measured
by the [Clean Water Act](/wiki/Clean_Water_Act "Clean Water Act"). 70% of the
population drank water that violated U.S. law.[158]

#### Rebuilding efforts

A tourism web site report in March 2018 indicated that all airports were
operating, although Luis Munoz Marin Airport would not be back to handling the
full number of flights until July 2018. Some 90% of the island was receiving
electricity, although the power structure would require another $17.6 billion
for full rebuilding, according to the [United States Department of
Energy](/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Energy "United States Department of
Energy").[159] Nearly all residents had access to telecommunications service
and running water. All hospitals were operating. Some 83% of hotel rooms were
available for use and the cruise ship port was receiving ships; 58 arrived in
San Juan in February. The island was encouraging operators to increase the
number of tourists.[160]

Reports in April 2018 stated that Puerto Rico will receive $18.5 billion from
the [United States Department of Housing and Urban
Development](/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Housing_and_Urban_Development
"United States Department of Housing and Urban Development") to help rebuild
homes and infrastructure. This was substantially less than the $46 billion
requested by the governor. However, the island was expecting to receive
approximately $50 billion for disaster relief over the subsequent six years
mostly via the [Federal Emergency Management
Agency](/wiki/Federal_Emergency_Management_Agency "Federal Emergency
Management Agency").[161] At that time, nearly 2800 families were living in
FEMA-sponsored short-term housing across 34 states and Puerto Rico. Nearly
half of the schools are operating at only 60% classroom capacity. Over 280
public schools would not reopen in the fall; 827 were expected to be
operational. Almost 40,000 students left the island's schools since May 2017;
some of these were in schools in the mainland U.S. (Before the hurricanes,
Puerto Rico had planned to close 179 schools due to inadequate numbers of
students.)[159]

#### Death toll

The official number of Hurricane Maria-related deaths as reported by the
government of Puerto Rico is 64. The Commonwealth has commissioned [George
Washington University](/wiki/George_Washington_University "George Washington
University") to assess the death toll and is awaiting that report.[162] An
academic study based on household surveys and reported in the [New England
Journal of Medicine](/wiki/New_England_Journal_of_Medicine "New England
Journal of Medicine") estimated that the number of hurricane-related deaths
during the period September 20, 2017 to December 31, 2017 was around 4,600
(range 793-8,498)[163]

## Geography

Main articles: [Geography of Puerto Rico](/wiki/Geography_of_Puerto_Rico
"Geography of Puerto Rico") and [Geology of Puerto
Rico](/wiki/Geology_of_Puerto_Rico "Geology of Puerto Rico")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Rico_%281%29.png/550px-
Rico_%281%29.png)](/wiki/File:Rico_\(1\).png)

[](/wiki/File:Rico_\(1\).png "Enlarge")

A map of Puerto Rico

Puerto Rico consists of the main island of Puerto Rico and various smaller
islands, including [Vieques](/wiki/Vieques,_Puerto_Rico "Vieques, Puerto
Rico"), [Culebra](/wiki/Culebra,_Puerto_Rico "Culebra, Puerto Rico"),
[Mona](/wiki/Mona,_Puerto_Rico "Mona, Puerto Rico"),
[Desecheo](/wiki/Desecheo_Island "Desecheo Island"), and [Caja de
Muertos](/wiki/Caja_de_Muertos,_Puerto_Rico "Caja de Muertos, Puerto Rico").
Of these five, only Culebra and Vieques are inhabited year-round. Mona, which
has played a key role in maritime history, is uninhabited most of the year
except for employees of the [Puerto Rico Department of Natural
Resources](/wiki/Department_of_Natural_and_Environmental_Resources_\(Puerto_Rico\)
"Department of Natural and Environmental Resources \(Puerto Rico\)").[164]
There are many other even smaller [islets](/wiki/Islets "Islets"), like
[Monito](/wiki/Monito_Island "Monito Island"), which is near to Mona,[165]
[Isla de Cabras](/wiki/Isla_de_Cabras "Isla de Cabras") and [La Isleta de San
Juan](/wiki/Isleta_de_San_Juan "Isleta de San Juan"), both located on the [San
Juan Bay](/wiki/San_Juan_Bay "San Juan Bay"). The latter is the only inhabited
islet with communities like [Old San Juan](/wiki/Old_San_Juan "Old San Juan")
and [Puerta de Tierra](/wiki/Puerta_de_Tierra "Puerta de Tierra"), and
connected to the main island by bridges.[166][167]

The Commonwealth of Puerto Rico has an area of 13,790 square kilometers (5,320
sq mi), of which 8,870 km2 (3,420 sq mi) is land and 4,921 km2 (1,900 sq mi)
is water.[168] Puerto Rico is larger than two U.S. states, Delaware and Rhode
Island. The maximum length of the main island from east to west is 180 km (110
mi), and the maximum width from north to south is 65 km (40 mi).[169] Puerto
Rico is the smallest of the Greater Antilles. It is 80% of the size of
[Jamaica](/wiki/Jamaica "Jamaica"),[170] just over 18% of the size of
[Hispaniola](/wiki/Hispaniola "Hispaniola") and 8% of the size of Cuba, the
largest of the Greater Antilles.[171]

The island is mostly mountainous with large coastal areas in the north and
south. The main mountain range is called "[La Cordillera
Central](/wiki/Cordillera_Central_\(Puerto_Rico\) "Cordillera Central \(Puerto
Rico\)")" (The Central Range). The highest elevation in Puerto Rico, [Cerro de
Punta](/wiki/Cerro_de_Punta "Cerro de Punta") 1,338 meters (4,390 ft),[168] is
located in this range.

Another important peak is [El Yunque](/wiki/El_Yunque,_Puerto_Rico "El Yunque,
Puerto Rico"), one of the highest in the _Sierra de Luquillo_ at the [El
Yunque National Forest](/wiki/El_Yunque_National_Forest "El Yunque National
Forest"), with an elevation of 1,065 m (3,494 ft).[172]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Patillas_Puerto_Rico.jpg/300px-
Patillas_Puerto_Rico.jpg)](/wiki/File:Patillas_Puerto_Rico.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Patillas_Puerto_Rico.jpg "Enlarge")

The coast at Patillas, Puerto Rico

Puerto Rico has 17 lakes, all man-made, and more than [50
rivers](/wiki/List_of_Puerto_Rico_rivers "List of Puerto Rico rivers"), most
originating in the Cordillera Central.[173] Rivers in the northern region of
the island are typically longer and of higher [water flow
rates](/wiki/Volumetric_flow_rate "Volumetric flow rate") than those of the
south, since the south receives less rain than the central and northern
regions.

Puerto Rico is composed of [Cretaceous](/wiki/Cretaceous "Cretaceous") to
[Eocene](/wiki/Eocene "Eocene") [volcanic](/wiki/Volcanic "Volcanic") and
[plutonic](/wiki/Plutonic "Plutonic") rocks, overlain by younger
[Oligocene](/wiki/Oligocene "Oligocene") and more recent
[carbonates](/wiki/Carbonate "Carbonate") and other [sedimentary
rocks](/wiki/Sedimentary_rocks "Sedimentary rocks").[174] Most of the
[caverns](/wiki/Caverns "Caverns") and [karst](/wiki/Karst "Karst") topography
on the island occurs in the northern region in the carbonates. The oldest
rocks are approximately 190 million years old ([Jurassic](/wiki/Jurassic
"Jurassic")) and are located at Sierra Bermeja in the southwest part of the
island. They may represent part of the [oceanic crust](/wiki/Oceanic_crust
"Oceanic crust") and are believed to come from the Pacific Ocean realm.

Puerto Rico lies at the boundary between the Caribbean and North American
[plates](/wiki/Plate_tectonics "Plate tectonics") and is being deformed by the
[tectonic](/wiki/Tectonics "Tectonics") stresses caused by their interaction.
These stresses may cause [earthquakes](/wiki/Earthquakes "Earthquakes") and
[tsunamis](/wiki/Tsunami "Tsunami"). These [seismic](/wiki/Seismic "Seismic")
events, along with [landslides](/wiki/Landslide "Landslide"), represent some
of the most dangerous [geologic hazards](/wiki/Geologic_hazards "Geologic
hazards") in the island and in the northeastern Caribbean.

The [most recent major earthquake](/wiki/1918_San_Ferm%C3%ADn_earthquake "1918
San Fermín earthquake") occurred on October 11, 1918, and had an estimated
magnitude of 7.5 on the [Richter scale](/wiki/Richter_magnitude_scale "Richter
magnitude scale").[175] It originated off the coast of
[Aguadilla](/wiki/Aguadilla "Aguadilla"), several kilometers off the northern
coast, and was accompanied by a [tsunami](/wiki/Tsunami "Tsunami"). It caused
extensive property damage and widespread losses, damaging infrastructure,
especially bridges. It resulted in an estimated 116 deaths and $4 million in
property damage. The failure of the government to move rapidly to provide for
the general welfare contributed to political activism by opponents and
eventually to the rise of the [Puerto Rican Nationalist
Party](/wiki/Puerto_Rican_Nationalist_Party "Puerto Rican Nationalist Party").

The [Puerto Rico Trench](/wiki/Puerto_Rico_Trench "Puerto Rico Trench"), the
largest and deepest trench in the Atlantic, is located about 115 km (71 mi)
north of Puerto Rico at the boundary between the Caribbean and North American
plates.[176] It is 280 km (170 mi) long.[177] At its deepest point, named the
[Milwaukee Deep](/wiki/Milwaukee_Deep "Milwaukee Deep"), it is almost 8,400 m
(27,600 ft) deep.[176]

### Climate

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/STS034-76-88.jpg/220px-
STS034-76-88.jpg)](/wiki/File:STS034-76-88.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:STS034-76-88.jpg "Enlarge")

Puerto Rico seen from [space](/wiki/Space "Space") ([STS-34](/wiki/STS-34
"STS-34") mission)

Main article: [Climate of Puerto Rico](/wiki/Climate_of_Puerto_Rico "Climate
of Puerto Rico")

The climate of Puerto Rico in the Köppen climate classification is [tropical
rainforest](/wiki/Tropical_rainforest "Tropical rainforest"). Temperatures are
warm to hot year round, averaging near 85 °F (29 °C) in lower elevations and
70 °F (21 °C) in the mountains. Easterly trade winds pass across the island
year round. Puerto Rico has a rainy season which stretches from April into
November. The mountains of the Cordillera Central are the main cause of the
variations in the temperature and rainfall that occur over very short
distances. The mountains can also cause wide variation in local wind speed and
direction due to their sheltering and channeling effects adding to the
climatic variation.

The island has an average temperature of 82.4 °F (28 °C) throughout the year,
with an average minimum temperature of 66.9 °F (19 °C) and maximum of 85.4 °F
(30 °C). Daily temperature changes seasonally are quite small in the lowlands
and coastal areas. The temperature in the south is usually a few degrees
higher than the north and temperatures in the central interior mountains are
always cooler than those on the rest of the island.

Between the dry and wet season, there is a temperature change of around 6 °F
(3.3 °C). This is mainly due to the warm waters of the tropical [Atlantic
Ocean](/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean "Atlantic Ocean"), which significantly modify
cooler air moving in from the north and northwest. Coastal waters temperatures
around the years are about 75 °F (24 °C) in February to 85 °F (29 °C) in
August. The highest temperature ever recorded was 99 °F (37 °C) at
[Arecibo](/wiki/Arecibo,_Puerto_Rico "Arecibo, Puerto Rico"),[178] while the
lowest temperature ever recorded was 40 °F (4 °C) in the mountains at
[Adjuntas](/wiki/Adjuntas,_Puerto_Rico "Adjuntas, Puerto Rico"),
[Aibonito](/wiki/Aibonito,_Puerto_Rico "Aibonito, Puerto Rico"), and
[Corozal](/wiki/Corozal,_Puerto_Rico "Corozal, Puerto Rico").[179] The average
yearly precipitation is 1,687 mm (66 in).[180]

Puerto Rico experiences the [Atlantic hurricane
season](/wiki/Atlantic_hurricane_season "Atlantic hurricane season"), similar
to the remainder of the Caribbean Sea and North Atlantic oceans. On average, a
quarter of its annual rainfall is contributed from tropical cyclones, which
are more prevalent during periods of La Niña than [El Niño](/wiki/El_Ni%C3%B1o
"El Niño").[181] A cyclone of tropical storm strength passes near Puerto Rico,
on average, every five years. A hurricane passes in the vicinity of the
island, on average, every seven years. Since 1851, the [Lake Okeechobee
Hurricane](/wiki/1928_Okeechobee_Hurricane "1928 Okeechobee Hurricane") of
September 1928 is the only hurricane to make landfall as a Category 5
hurricane.[182]

In the busy [2017 Atlantic hurricane
season](/wiki/2017_Atlantic_hurricane_season "2017 Atlantic hurricane
season"), Puerto Rico avoided a direct hit by the Category 5 [Hurricane
Irma](/wiki/Hurricane_Irma "Hurricane Irma") on September 8, 2017, but high
winds caused a loss of electrical power to some one million residents. Almost
50% of hospitals were operating with power provided by generators.[183] The
Category 4 [Hurricane Jose](/wiki/Hurricane_Jose_\(2017\) "Hurricane Jose
\(2017\)"), as expected, veered away from Puerto Rico.[184] A short time
later, the devastating [Hurricane Maria](/wiki/Hurricane_Maria "Hurricane
Maria") made landfall in Puerto Rico as a Category 4 hurricane, with sustained
155 mph (249 km/h) winds, powerful rains and widespread flooding causing
tremendous destruction, including the electrical grid, which could remain out
for 4–6 months.[185][186][187] With such widespread destruction and a great
need for supplies – everything from drinking water, food, medicine and
personal care items to fuel for generators and construction materials for
rebuilding the island – Gov. Rossello and several Congressmen called on the
federal government to waive the WWI-era Jones Act (protectionist provisions:
ships made and owned in U.S., and with U.S. crews), which essentially double
Puerto Rico's cost for shipped goods relative to neighboring islands. On
September 28, U.S. President [Donald Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump")
waived the Act for ten days.[188]

### Biodiversity

Main articles: [Fauna of Puerto Rico](/wiki/Fauna_of_Puerto_Rico "Fauna of
Puerto Rico") and [Flora of Puerto Rico](/wiki/Flora_of_Puerto_Rico "Flora of
Puerto Rico")

[!["In this image there is a brown coquí. The species resembles a small
frog."](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Common_Coqu%C3%AD.jpg/150px-
Common_Coqu%C3%AD.jpg)](/wiki/File:Common_Coqu%C3%AD.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Common_Coqu%C3%AD.jpg "Enlarge")

Common Coquí

Species [endemic](/wiki/Endemic_\(ecology\) "Endemic \(ecology\)") to the
archipelago number 239 plants, 16 birds and 39 [amphibians](/wiki/Amphibian
"Amphibian")/[reptiles](/wiki/Reptile "Reptile"), recognized as of 1998. Most
of these (234, 12 and 33 respectively) are found on the main island.[189] The
most recognizable endemic species and a symbol of Puerto Rican pride is the
_[coquí](/wiki/Coqu%C3%AD "Coquí")_ , a small frog easily identified by the
sound of its call, from which it gets its name. Most _coquí_ species (13 of
17) live in the [El Yunque National Forest](/wiki/El_Yunque_National_Forest
"El Yunque National Forest"), a [tropical
rainforest](/wiki/Tropical_and_subtropical_moist_broadleaf_forests "Tropical
and subtropical moist broadleaf forests") in the northeast of the island
previously known as the Caribbean National Forest. El Yunque is home to more
than 240 plants, 26 of which are endemic to the island. It is also home to 50
bird species, including the critically endangered [Puerto Rican
amazon](/wiki/Puerto_Rican_amazon "Puerto Rican amazon").

Across the island in the southwest, the 40 km2 (15 sq mi) of dry land at the
Guánica Commonwealth Forest Reserve[190] contain over 600 uncommon species of
plants and animals, including 48 endangered species and 16 endemic to Puerto
Rico.

## Demographics

Main articles: [Demographics of Puerto Rico](/wiki/Demographics_of_Puerto_Rico
"Demographics of Puerto Rico") and [Cultural diversity in Puerto
Rico](/wiki/Cultural_diversity_in_Puerto_Rico "Cultural diversity in Puerto
Rico")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f2/Population_Density%2C_PR%2C_2000_%28sample%29.jpg/350px-
Population_Density%2C_PR%2C_2000_%28sample%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Population_Density,_PR,_2000_\(sample\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Population_Density,_PR,_2000_\(sample\).jpg "Enlarge")

Population density, Census 2000

The population of Puerto Rico has been shaped by [Amerindian
settlement](/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas "Indigenous peoples of
the Americas"), [European colonization](/wiki/Spanish_Empire "Spanish
Empire"), [slavery](/wiki/Slavery "Slavery"), economic migration, and Puerto
Rico's status as unincorporated territory of the United States.

The estimated population of Puerto Rico as of July 1, 2015, was 3,474,182, a
6.75% decrease since the [2010 United States
Census](/wiki/2010_United_States_Census "2010 United States Census").[193]
From 2000 to 2010, the population decreased, the first such decrease in census
history for Puerto Rico. It went from the 3,808,610 residents registered in
the 2000 Census to 3,725,789 in the 2010 Census.[194]

A declining and aging population presents additional problems for the society.
The U.S. Census Bureau's estimate for July 1, 2016 was 3,411,307 people, down
substantially from the 2010 data which had indicated 3,725,789 people.[195]

Continuous European immigration and high [natural
increase](/wiki/Natural_increase "Natural increase") helped the population of
Puerto Rico grow from 155,426 in 1800, to almost a million by the close of the
19th century.

A census conducted by royal decree on September 30, 1858, gave the following
totals of the Puerto Rican population at that time: 341,015 were Free
[colored](/wiki/Colored "Colored"); 300,430 identified as
[Whites](/wiki/White_people "White people"); and 41,736 were
[slaves](/wiki/Slaves "Slaves").[196]

During the 19th century hundreds of families arrived in Puerto Rico, primarily
from the [Canary Islands](/wiki/Canary_Islands "Canary Islands") and
[Andalusia](/wiki/Andalusia "Andalusia"), but also from other parts of Spain
such as [Catalonia](/wiki/Catalonia "Catalonia"), [Asturias](/wiki/Asturias
"Asturias"), [Galicia](/wiki/Galicia_\(Spain\) "Galicia \(Spain\)") and the
[Balearic Islands](/wiki/Balearic_Islands "Balearic Islands") and numerous
Spanish loyalists from Spain's former colonies in South America. Settlers from
outside Spain also arrived in the islands, including from
[Corsica](/wiki/Corsica "Corsica"), [France](/wiki/France "France"),
[Lebanon](/wiki/Lebanon "Lebanon"),
[China](/wiki/Chinese_immigration_to_Puerto_Rico "Chinese immigration to
Puerto Rico"), [Portugal](/wiki/Portugal "Portugal"),
[Ireland](/wiki/Irish_immigration_to_Puerto_Rico "Irish immigration to Puerto
Rico"), [Scotland](/wiki/Scotland "Scotland"),
[Germany](/wiki/German_immigration_to_Puerto_Rico "German immigration to
Puerto Rico") and [Italy](/wiki/Italian_people "Italian people"). This
immigration from non-Hispanic countries was the result of the _Real Cedula de
Gracias de 1815_ ("[Royal Decree of Graces of
1815](/wiki/Royal_Decree_of_Graces_of_1815 "Royal Decree of Graces of
1815")"), which allowed European Catholics to settle in the island with land
allotments in the interior of the island, provided they paid taxes and
continued to support the Catholic Church.

Between 1960 and 1990 the census questionnaire in Puerto Rico did not ask
about race or ethnicity. The [2000 United States
Census](/wiki/2000_United_States_Census "2000 United States Census") included
a racial self-identification question in Puerto Rico. According to the census,
most Puerto Ricans identified as White and Hispanic; few identified as Black
or some other race.

#### Population genetics

A recent [population genetics](/wiki/Population_genetics "Population
genetics") study conducted in Puerto Rico suggests that between 52.6% and 84%
of the population possess some degree of Amerindian [mitochondrial
DNA](/wiki/Mitochondrial_DNA "Mitochondrial DNA") (mtDNA) in their maternal
ancestry, usually in a combination with other ancestries such as aboriginal
[Guanche](/wiki/Guanches "Guanches") North-West African ancestry brought by
Spanish settlers from the Canary Islands.[198]

In addition, these DNA studies show Amerindian ancestry in addition to the
Taíno.[199][200][201][202]

One genetic study on the racial makeup of Puerto Ricans (including all races)
found them to be roughly around 61% [West Eurasian](/wiki/West_Eurasian "West
Eurasian")/[North African](/wiki/North_Africa "North Africa") (overwhelmingly
of Spanish provenance), 27% [Sub-Saharan African](/wiki/Sub-Saharan_African
"Sub-Saharan African") and 11% [Native
American](/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas "Indigenous peoples of the
Americas").[203] Another genetic study from 2007, claimed that "the average
genomewide individual (ie. Puerto Rican) ancestry proportions have been
estimated as 66%, 18%, and 16%, for European, West African, and Native
American, respectively."[204] Other study estimates 63.7% European, 21.2%
(Sub-Saharan) African, and 15.2% Native American; European ancestry is more
prevalent in the West and in Central Puerto Rico, African in Eastern Puerto
Rico, and Native American in Northern Puerto Rico.[205]

A Pew Research survey indicated a literacy rate of 90.4% (adult population) in
2012 based on data from the [United Nations](/wiki/United_Nations "United
Nations") and a life expectancy of 79.3 years.[206]

### Immigration and emigration

Racial groups  
---  
Year | Population | White | Mixed (mainly biracial white European and black African ) | Black | Asian | Other   
2000  | 3,808,610  | 80.5% (3 064 862)  | 11.0% (418 426)  | 8.0% (302 933)  | 0.2% (7 960)  | 0.4% (14 429)   
2010  | 3,725,789  | 75.8% ('2 824 148)  | 11.1% ('413 563)  | 12.4% ('461 998)  | 0.2% ('7 452)  | 0.6% ('22 355)   
  
Puerto Rico has
recently[_[when?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items
"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers")_] become the permanent home of
over 100,000 legal residents. The vast majority of recent immigrants, both
legal and illegal, come from the [Dominican
Republic](/wiki/Dominican_Republic_immigration_to_Puerto_Rico "Dominican
Republic immigration to Puerto Rico") and [Haiti](/wiki/Haitian_diaspora
"Haitian diaspora").[207][208][209][210][211] Other sources sending in
significant numbers of recent immigrants include [Cuba](/wiki/Cuba "Cuba"),
[Mexico](/wiki/Mexico "Mexico"), [Colombia](/wiki/Colombia "Colombia"),
[Panama](/wiki/Panama "Panama"), [Jamaica](/wiki/Jamaica "Jamaica"),
[Venezuela](/wiki/Venezuela "Venezuela"), [Spain](/wiki/Spain "Spain"), and
[Nigeria](/wiki/Nigeria "Nigeria").[212][213] Also, there are many non-Puerto
Rican U.S. citizens settling in Puerto Rico, from the mainland United States
and the [U.S. Virgin Islands](/wiki/U.S._Virgin_Islands "U.S. Virgin
Islands"), as well as [Nuyoricans](/wiki/Nuyorican "Nuyorican") (stateside
Puerto Ricans) coming back to Puerto Rico.[214] Most recent immigrants settle
in and around San Juan.

[Emigration](/wiki/Emigration "Emigration") is a major part of contemporary
Puerto Rican history. Starting soon after [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II
"World War II"), poverty, cheap airfares, and promotion by the island
government caused waves of Puerto Ricans to move to the United States,
particularly to the [Northeastern states](/wiki/Northeastern_United_States
"Northeastern United States"), and [Florida](/wiki/Florida "Florida").[215]
This trend continued even as Puerto Rico's economy improved and its birth rate
declined. Puerto Ricans continue to follow a pattern of "[circular
migration](/wiki/Circular_migration "Circular migration")", with some migrants
returning to the island. In recent years, the population has declined
markedly, falling nearly 1% in 2012 and an additional 1% (36,000 people) in
2013 due to a falling birthrate and emigration.[216]

According to the 2010 Census, the number of Puerto Ricans living in the United
States outside of Puerto Rico far exceeds those living in Puerto Rico.
Emigration exceeds immigration. As those who leave tend to be better educated
than those that remain, this accentuates the drain on Puerto Rico’s economy.

Based on the July 1, 2016 estimate by the U.S. Census Bureau, the population
of the Commonwealth had declined by 314,482 people since the 2010 Census data
had been tabulated.[195]

### Population distribution

The most populous city is the capital, [San Juan](/wiki/San_Juan,_Puerto_Rico
"San Juan, Puerto Rico"), with approximately 371,400 people based on a 2015
estimate by the Census Bureau.[217] Other major cities include
[Bayamón](/wiki/Bayam%C3%B3n,_Puerto_Rico "Bayamón, Puerto Rico"),
[Carolina](/wiki/Carolina,_Puerto_Rico "Carolina, Puerto Rico"),
[Ponce](/wiki/Ponce,_Puerto_Rico "Ponce, Puerto Rico"), and
[Caguas](/wiki/Caguas,_Puerto_Rico "Caguas, Puerto Rico"). Of the ten most
populous cities on the island, eight are located within what is considered
[San Juan's metropolitan area](/wiki/San_Juan-Caguas-
Guaynabo_metropolitan_area "San Juan-Caguas-Guaynabo metropolitan area"),
while the other two are located in the south
([Ponce](/wiki/Ponce_metropolitan_area "Ponce metropolitan area")) and west
([Mayagüez](/wiki/Mayag%C3%BCez_metropolitan_area "Mayagüez metropolitan
area")) of the island.

### Languages

The [official languages](/wiki/Official_language "Official language")[219] of
the executive branch of government of Puerto Rico[220] are Spanish and
English, with Spanish being the primary language. Spanish is, and has been,
the only official language of the entire Commonwealth judiciary system,
despite a 1902 English-only language law.[221] However, all official business
of the [U.S. District Court](/wiki/U.S._District_Court "U.S. District Court")
for the District of Puerto Rico is conducted in English. English is the
primary language of less than 10% of the population. Spanish is the dominant
language of business, education and daily life on the island, spoken by nearly
95% of the population.[222]

The U.S. Census Bureau's 2015 update provides the following facts:[2] 94.1% of
adults speak Spanish, 5.8% speak only English, 78.3% do not speak English
"very well".

In Puerto Rico, public school instruction is conducted almost entirely in
Spanish. There have been pilot programs in about a dozen of the over 1,400
public schools aimed at conducting instruction in English only. Objections
from teaching staff are common, perhaps because many of them are not fully
fluent in English.[223] English is taught as a second language and is a
compulsory subject from elementary levels to high school. The languages of the
deaf community are [American Sign Language](/wiki/American_Sign_Language
"American Sign Language") and its local variant, [Puerto Rican Sign
Language](/wiki/Puerto_Rican_Sign_Language "Puerto Rican Sign Language").

The Spanish of Puerto Rico has evolved into having many idiosyncrasies in
vocabulary and syntax that differentiate it from the Spanish spoken elsewhere.
As a product of Puerto Rican history, the island possesses a unique Spanish
dialect. Puerto Rican Spanish utilizes many [Taíno](/wiki/Ta%C3%ADno_language
"Taíno language") words, as well as English words. The largest influence on
the Spanish spoken in Puerto Rico is that of the Canary Islands. Taíno
[loanwords](/wiki/Loanword "Loanword") are most often used in the context of
vegetation, natural phenomena, and native musical instruments. Similarly,
words attributed to primarily West [African languages](/wiki/African_languages
"African languages") were adopted in the contexts of foods, music, and dances,
particularly in coastal towns with concentrations of descendants of Sub-
Saharan Africans.[224]

### Religion

Religious affiliation in Puerto Rico (2014)[225][226]

[Roman Catholic](/wiki/Roman_Catholic "Roman Catholic") (56%)

[Protestant](/wiki/Protestant "Protestant") (33%)

Other (3%)

[Irreligious](/wiki/Irreligious "Irreligious") (8%)

The [Roman Catholic Church](/wiki/Roman_Catholicism_in_Puerto_Rico "Roman
Catholicism in Puerto Rico") was brought by Spanish colonists and gradually
became the dominant religion in Puerto Rico. The first
[dioceses](/wiki/Dioceses "Dioceses") in the Americas, including that of
Puerto Rico, were authorized by [Pope Julius II](/wiki/Pope_Julius_II "Pope
Julius II") in 1511.[227] One Pope, [John Paul II](/wiki/John_Paul_II "John
Paul II"), visited Puerto Rico in October 1984. All
[municipalities](/wiki/Municipalities_of_Puerto_Rico "Municipalities of Puerto
Rico") in Puerto Rico have at least one Catholic church, most of which are
located at the town center, or plaza. African slaves brought and maintained
various ethnic African religious practices associated with different peoples;
in particular, the [Yoruba](/wiki/Yoruba_religion "Yoruba religion") beliefs
of [Santería](/wiki/Santer%C3%ADa "Santería") and/or [Ifá](/wiki/If%C3%A1
"Ifá"), and the [Kongo](/wiki/Kongo_people "Kongo people")-derived [Palo
Mayombe](/wiki/Palo_Mayombe "Palo Mayombe"). Some aspects were absorbed into
syncretic Christianity.

[Protestantism](/wiki/Protestantism_in_Puerto_Rico "Protestantism in Puerto
Rico"), which was suppressed under the Spanish Catholic regime, has slightly
reemerged under United States rule, making contemporary Puerto Rico more
interconfessional than in previous centuries, although Catholicism continues
to be the dominant religion. The first Protestant church, [Iglesia de la
Santísima Trinidad](/wiki/Iglesia_de_la_Sant%C3%ADsima_Trinidad "Iglesia de la
Santísima Trinidad"), was established in Ponce by the
[Anglican](/wiki/Anglican "Anglican") [Diocese of
Antigua](/wiki/Diocese_of_Antigua "Diocese of Antigua") in 1872.[228] It was
the first non-Roman Catholic Church in the entire [Spanish
Empire](/wiki/Spanish_Empire "Spanish Empire") in [the
Americas](/wiki/The_Americas "The Americas").[229][230]

Pollster Pablo Ramos stated in 1998 that the population was 38% Roman
Catholic, 28% Pentecostal, and 18% were members of independent churches, which
would give a Protestant percentage of 46% if the last two populations are
combined. Protestants collectively added up to almost two million people.
Another researcher gave a more conservative assessment of the proportion of
Protestants:

> Puerto Rico, by virtue of its long political association with the United
> States, is the most Protestant of Latin American countries, with a
> Protestant population of approximately 33 to 38 percent, the majority of
> whom are [Pentecostal](/wiki/Pentecostal "Pentecostal"). David Stoll
> calculates that if we extrapolate the growth rates of evangelical churches
> from 1960–1985 for another twenty-five years Puerto Rico will become 75
> percent evangelical. (Ana Adams: "Brincando el Charco..." in _Power,
> Politics and Pentecostals in Latin America_ , Edward Cleary, ed., 1997. p.
> 164).[231]

The data provided for 2014 by [Pew Research Center](/wiki/Pew_Research_Center
"Pew Research Center"),[206] is summarized in the chart to the right. An
[Associated Press](/wiki/Associated_Press "Associated Press") article in March
2014 stated that "more than 70 percent of whom identify themselves as
Catholic" but provided no source for this information.[232]

The CIA World Factbook reports that 85% of the population of Puerto Rico
identifies as Roman Catholic, while 15% identify as Protestant and Other.
Neither a date or a source for that information is provided and may not be
recent.[233] A 2013 Pew Research survey found that only about 45% of Puerto
Rican adults identified themselves as Catholic, 29% as Protestant and 20% as
unaffiliated with a religion. The people surveyed by Pew consisted of Puerto
Ricans living in the 50 states and DC and may not be indicative of those
living in the Commonwealth.[234]

By 2014, a Pew Research report, with the sub-title _Widespread Change in a
Historically Catholic Region_ , indicated that only 56% of Puerto Ricans were
Catholic and that 33% were Protestant; this survey was completed between
October 2013 and February 2014.[235]

An [Eastern Orthodox](/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox "Eastern Orthodox") community,
the Dormition of the Most Holy Theotokos / St. Spyridon's Church is located in
Trujillo Alto, and serves the small Orthodox community. This affiliation
accounted for under 1% of the population in 2010 according to the Pew Research
report.[236] In 1940, [Juanita García Peraza](/wiki/Juanita_Garc%C3%ADa_Peraza
"Juanita García Peraza") founded the [Mita
Congregation](/wiki/Mita_Congregation "Mita Congregation"), the first religion
of Puerto Rican origin.[237] [Taíno religious
practices](/wiki/Ta%C3%ADno_people "Taíno people") have been
rediscovered/reinvented to a degree by a handful of advocates. Similarly, some
aspects of African religious traditions have been kept by some adherents. In
1952, a handful of American Jews established the island's first
[synagogue](/wiki/Synagogue "Synagogue"); this religion accounts for under 1%
of the population in 2010 according to the Pew Research report.[238][239] The
synagogue, called _Sha 'are Zedeck_, hired its first rabbi in 1954.[240]
Puerto Rico has the largest Jewish community in the Caribbean, numbering 3000
people (date not stated),[241] and is the only Caribbean island in which the
[Conservative](/wiki/Conservative_Jews "Conservative Jews"),
[Reform](/wiki/Reform_Jews "Reform Jews") and [Orthodox
Jewish](/wiki/Orthodox_Jews "Orthodox Jews") movements all are
represented.[240][242] In 2007, there were about 5,000 Muslims in Puerto Rico,
representing about 0.13% of the population.[243][244] Eight
[mosques](/wiki/Mosques "Mosques") are located throughout the island, with
most Muslims living in [Río Piedras](/wiki/R%C3%ADo_Piedras "Río Piedras") and
[Caguas](/wiki/Caguas "Caguas"), most of these Muslims are of Palestinian and
Jordanian descent.[245][246] There is also a [Bahá'í](/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%27%C3%AD
"Bahá'í") community on the island.[247] In 2015, the 25,832 [Jehovah's
Witnesses](/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witnesses "Jehovah's Witnesses") represented
about 0.70% of the population, with 324 congregations.[248] The [Padmasambhava
Buddhist Center](/wiki/Chinese_immigration_to_Puerto_Rico "Chinese immigration
to Puerto Rico"), whose followers practice [Tibetan
Buddhism](/wiki/Tibetan_Buddhism "Tibetan Buddhism"), as well as [Nichiren
Buddhism](/wiki/Nichiren_Buddhism "Nichiren Buddhism") have branches in Puerto
Rico.[249] There are several atheist activist and educational organizations,
and an atheistic parody religion called the [Pastafarian](/wiki/Pastafarian
"Pastafarian") Church of Puerto Rico.[250]

  * [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/San_Juan_Cathedral.JPG/90px-San_Juan_Cathedral.JPG)](/wiki/File:San_Juan_Cathedral.JPG)

## Government

Main articles: [Government of Puerto Rico](/wiki/Government_of_Puerto_Rico
"Government of Puerto Rico") and [Politics of Puerto
Rico](/wiki/Politics_of_Puerto_Rico "Politics of Puerto Rico")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Ricardo_Rossello.jpg/260px-
Ricardo_Rossello.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ricardo_Rossello.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ricardo_Rossello.jpg "Enlarge")

Governor of Puerto Rico, [Ricardo Rosselló](/wiki/Ricardo_Rossell%C3%B3
"Ricardo Rosselló")

Puerto Rico has [8 senatorial
districts](/wiki/Puerto_Rico_senatorial_districts "Puerto Rico senatorial
districts"), [40 representative
districts](/wiki/Puerto_Rico_representative_districts "Puerto Rico
representative districts") and [78
municipalities](/wiki/Municipalities_of_Puerto_Rico "Municipalities of Puerto
Rico"). It has a republican form of government with [separation of
powers](/wiki/Separation_of_powers "Separation of powers") subject to the
jurisdiction and sovereignty of the United States.[251][252] Its current
powers are all delegated by the [United States
Congress](/wiki/United_States_Congress "United States Congress") and lack full
protection under the [United States
Constitution](/wiki/United_States_Constitution "United States
Constitution").[253] Puerto Rico's head of state is the [President of the
United States](/wiki/President_of_the_United_States "President of the United
States").

The government of Puerto Rico, based on [the formal republican
system](/wiki/Republicanism_in_the_United_States "Republicanism in the United
States"), is composed of three branches: the
[executive](/wiki/Executive_branch_of_the_government_of_Puerto_Rico "Executive
branch of the government of Puerto Rico"),
[legislative](/wiki/Legislative_branch_of_the_government_of_Puerto_Rico
"Legislative branch of the government of Puerto Rico"), and [judicial
branch](/wiki/Judiciary_of_Puerto_Rico "Judiciary of Puerto Rico"). The
executive branch is headed by the [governor](/wiki/Governor_of_Puerto_Rico
"Governor of Puerto Rico"), currently [Ricky
Rosselló](/wiki/Ricky_Rossell%C3%B3 "Ricky Rosselló"). The [legislative
branch](/wiki/Legislative_branch "Legislative branch") consists of a
[bicameral](/wiki/Bicameral "Bicameral") legislature called the [Legislative
Assembly](/wiki/Legislative_Assembly_of_Puerto_Rico "Legislative Assembly of
Puerto Rico"), made up of a [Senate](/wiki/Senate_of_Puerto_Rico "Senate of
Puerto Rico") as its upper chamber and a [House of
Representatives](/wiki/House_of_Representatives_of_Puerto_Rico "House of
Representatives of Puerto Rico") as its lower chamber. The Senate is headed by
the [President of the Senate](/wiki/President_of_the_Senate_of_Puerto_Rico
"President of the Senate of Puerto Rico"), currently [Thomas Rivera
Schatz](/wiki/Thomas_Rivera_Schatz "Thomas Rivera Schatz"), while the House of
Representatives is headed by the [Speaker of the
House](/wiki/Speaker_of_the_House_of_Representatives_of_Puerto_Rico "Speaker
of the House of Representatives of Puerto Rico"), currently [Johnny
Méndez](/wiki/Carlos_Johnny_M%C3%A9ndez "Carlos Johnny Méndez"). The governor
and legislators are elected by popular vote every four years with [the last
election held in November 2016](/wiki/Puerto_Rican_general_election,_2016
"Puerto Rican general election, 2016").

The [judicial branch](/wiki/Judiciary_of_Puerto_Rico "Judiciary of Puerto
Rico") is headed by the [Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of Puerto
Rico](/wiki/Chief_Justice_of_the_Supreme_Court_of_Puerto_Rico "Chief Justice
of the Supreme Court of Puerto Rico"), currently [Maite Oronoz
Rodríguez](/wiki/Maite_Oronoz_Rodr%C3%ADguez "Maite Oronoz Rodríguez").
Members of the judicial branch are appointed by the governor with the [advice
and consent](/wiki/Advice_and_consent "Advice and consent") of the Senate.

Puerto Rico is represented in the United States Congress by a nonvoting
delegate, the [Resident
Commissioner](/wiki/Resident_Commissioner_of_Puerto_Rico "Resident
Commissioner of Puerto Rico"), currently [Jenniffer
González](/wiki/Jenniffer_Gonz%C3%A1lez "Jenniffer González"). Current
congressional rules have removed the Commissioner's power to vote in the
[Committee of the
Whole](/wiki/Committee_of_the_Whole_\(United_States_House_of_Representatives\)
"Committee of the Whole \(United States House of Representatives\)"), but the
Commissioner can vote in committee.[254]

Puerto Rican elections are governed by the [Federal Election
Commission](/wiki/Federal_Election_Commission "Federal Election Commission")
and the [State Elections Commission of Puerto
Rico](/wiki/State_Elections_Commission_of_Puerto_Rico "State Elections
Commission of Puerto Rico").[255][_[not in citation
given](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")_][256][_[not
in citation given](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")_]
While residing in Puerto Rico, Puerto Ricans cannot vote in U.S. presidential
elections, but they can vote in
[primaries](/w/index.php?title=U.S._Presidential_Primary&action=edit&redlink=1
"U.S. Presidential Primary \(page does not exist\)"). Puerto Ricans who become
residents of a [U.S. state](/wiki/U.S._state "U.S. state") can vote in
presidential elections.

Puerto Rico hosts [consulates](/wiki/Consul_\(representative\) "Consul
\(representative\)") from 41 countries, mainly from the
[Americas](/wiki/Americas "Americas") and Europe, with most located in San
Juan.[257] As an unincorporated territory of the United States, Puerto Rico
does not have any first-order administrative divisions as defined by the U.S.
government, but has 78 [municipalities](/wiki/Municipalities "Municipalities")
at the second level. [Mona Island](/wiki/Mona_Island "Mona Island") is not a
municipality, but part of the municipality of
[Mayagüez](/wiki/Mayag%C3%BCez,_Puerto_Rico "Mayagüez, Puerto Rico").[258]

Municipalities are subdivided into wards or [barrios](/wiki/Barrio "Barrio"),
and those into sectors. Each municipality has a
[mayor](/wiki/Mayors_of_Puerto_Rico "Mayors of Puerto Rico") and a municipal
legislature elected for a four-year term. The municipality of [San
Juan](/wiki/San_Juan,_Puerto_Rico "San Juan, Puerto Rico") (previously called
"town"), was founded first, in 1521, [San Germán](/wiki/San_Germ%C3%A1n "San
Germán") in 1570, [Coamo](/wiki/Coamo "Coamo") in 1579,
[Arecibo](/wiki/Arecibo "Arecibo") in 1614, [Aguada](/wiki/Aguada,_Puerto_Rico
"Aguada, Puerto Rico") in 1692 and [Ponce](/wiki/Ponce,_Puerto_Rico "Ponce,
Puerto Rico") in 1692. An increase of settlement saw the founding of 30
municipalities in the 18th century and 34 in the 19th. Six were founded in the
20th century; the last was [Florida](/wiki/Florida,_Puerto_Rico "Florida,
Puerto Rico") in 1971.[259]

### Political parties and elections

Main article: [Political party strength in Puerto
Rico](/wiki/Political_party_strength_in_Puerto_Rico "Political party strength
in Puerto Rico")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Political-party-
strength-in-puerto-rico-2012.png/220px-Political-party-strength-in-puerto-
rico-2012.png)](/wiki/File:Political-party-strength-in-puerto-rico-2012.png)

[](/wiki/File:Political-party-strength-in-puerto-rico-2012.png "Enlarge")

The difference between the incumbent party, the PPD, and its opponent, the
PNP, was a mere 0.6% in the last election. This difference is common as the
political landscape experiences political cycles between both parties, with
the PPD ruling all branches of government for 36 of the past 64 years. The
PNP, on the other hand, has ruled both the executive and legislative branch
concurrently for 16 years. The other 12 years experienced a [divided
government](/wiki/Divided_government_in_the_United_States "Divided government
in the United States").

Since 1952, Puerto Rico has had three main political parties: the [Popular
Democratic Party](/wiki/Popular_Democratic_Party_of_Puerto_Rico "Popular
Democratic Party of Puerto Rico") (PPD in Spanish), the [New Progressive
Party](/wiki/New_Progressive_Party_of_Puerto_Rico "New Progressive Party of
Puerto Rico") (PNP in Spanish) and the [Puerto Rican Independence
Party](/wiki/Puerto_Rican_Independence_Party "Puerto Rican Independence
Party") (PIP). The three parties stand for different political status. The
PPD, for example, seeks [to maintain the island's status with the U.S. as a
commonwealth](/wiki/Status_quo_movement_in_Puerto_Rico "Status quo movement in
Puerto Rico"), while the PNP, on the other hand, seeks [to make Puerto Rico a
state of the United States](/wiki/Statehood_movement_in_Puerto_Rico "Statehood
movement in Puerto Rico"). The PIP, in contrast, seeks a complete separation
from the United States by seeking [to make Puerto Rico a sovereign
nation](/wiki/Independence_movement_in_Puerto_Rico "Independence movement in
Puerto Rico"). In terms of party strength, the PPD and PNP usually hold about
47% of the vote each while the PIP holds only about 5%.

After 2007, other parties emerged on the island. The first, the [Puerto Ricans
for Puerto Rico Party](/wiki/Puerto_Ricans_for_Puerto_Rico_Party "Puerto
Ricans for Puerto Rico Party") (PPR in Spanish) was registered that same year.
The party claims that it seeks to address the islands' problems from a status-
neutral platform. But it ceased to remain as a registered party when it failed
to obtain the required number of votes in the 2008 general election. Four
years later, the 2012 election saw the emergence of the [Movimiento Unión
Soberanista](/wiki/Movimiento_Uni%C3%B3n_Soberanista "Movimiento Unión
Soberanista") (MUS; English: _Sovereign Union Movement_) and the [Partido del
Pueblo Trabajador](/wiki/Partido_del_Pueblo_Trabajador "Partido del Pueblo
Trabajador") (PPT; English: _Working People 's Party_) but none obtained more
than 1% of the vote.

Other non-registered parties include the [Puerto Rican Nationalist
Party](/wiki/Puerto_Rican_Nationalist_Party "Puerto Rican Nationalist Party"),
the [Socialist Workers
Movement](/wiki/Socialist_Workers_Movement_\(Puerto_Rico\) "Socialist Workers
Movement \(Puerto Rico\)"), and the [Hostosian National Independence
Movement](/wiki/Hostosian_National_Independence_Movement "Hostosian National
Independence Movement").

### Law

Main articles: [Constitution of Puerto Rico](/wiki/Constitution_of_Puerto_Rico
"Constitution of Puerto Rico") and [Law of Puerto
Rico](/wiki/Law_of_Puerto_Rico "Law of Puerto Rico")

The insular legal system is a blend of [civil
law](/wiki/Civil_law_\(legal_system\) "Civil law \(legal system\)") and the
[common law](/wiki/Common_law "Common law") systems.

Puerto Rico is the only current U.S. possession whose legal system operates
primarily in a language other than American English: namely,
[Spanish](/wiki/Spanish_language "Spanish language"). Because the [U.S.
federal government](/wiki/Federal_government_of_the_United_States "Federal
government of the United States") operates primarily in English, all Puerto
Rican attorneys must be bilingual in order to litigate in English in [U.S.
federal courts](/wiki/United_States_federal_courts "United States federal
courts"), and litigate federal preemption issues in Puerto Rican courts.

[Title 48 of the United States Code](/wiki/Title_48_of_the_United_States_Code
"Title 48 of the United States Code") outlines the role of the United States
Code to United States territories and insular areas such as Puerto Rico. After
the U.S. government assumed control of Puerto Rico in 1901, it initiated legal
reforms resulting in the adoption of codes of criminal law, criminal
procedure, and civil procedure modeled after those then in effect in
[California](/wiki/California "California"). Although Puerto Rico has since
followed the federal example of transferring criminal and civil procedure from
statutory law to rules promulgated by the judiciary, several portions of its
criminal law still reflect the influence of the [California Penal
Code](/wiki/California_Penal_Code "California Penal Code").

The judicial branch is headed by the [Chief Justice](/wiki/Chief_Justice
"Chief Justice") of the [Puerto Rico Supreme
Court](/wiki/Puerto_Rico_Supreme_Court "Puerto Rico Supreme Court"), which is
the only appellate court required by the Constitution. All other courts are
created by the [Legislative Assembly of Puerto
Rico](/wiki/Legislative_Assembly_of_Puerto_Rico "Legislative Assembly of
Puerto Rico"). There is also a [Federal District Court for Puerto
Rico](/wiki/United_States_District_Court_for_the_District_of_Puerto_Rico
"United States District Court for the District of Puerto Rico"). Someone
accused of a criminal act at the federal level may not be accused for the same
act in a Commonwealth court, unlike a state court, since Puerto Rico as a
territory lacks sovereignty separate from Congress as a state does.[260] Such
a parallel accusation would constitute [double jeopardy](/wiki/Double_jeopardy
"Double jeopardy").

### Political status

Main articles: [Political status of Puerto
Rico](/wiki/Political_status_of_Puerto_Rico "Political status of Puerto Rico")
and [Proposed political status for Puerto
Rico](/wiki/Proposed_political_status_for_Puerto_Rico "Proposed political
status for Puerto Rico")

The nature of Puerto Rico's political relationship with the U.S. is the
subject of ongoing debate in Puerto Rico, the [United States
Congress](/wiki/United_States_Congress "United States Congress"), and the
[United Nations](/wiki/United_Nations "United Nations").[261] Specifically,
the basic question is whether Puerto Rico should remain a [U.S.
territory](/wiki/Territories_of_the_United_States "Territories of the United
States"), become a [U.S. state](/wiki/U.S._state "U.S. state"), or become an
independent country.[262]

#### Within the United States

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/PR_Capitol%2C_south_side.JPG/300px-
PR_Capitol%2C_south_side.JPG)](/wiki/File:PR_Capitol,_south_side.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:PR_Capitol,_south_side.JPG "Enlarge")

The [Capitol of Puerto Rico](/wiki/Capitol_of_Puerto_Rico "Capitol of Puerto
Rico"), home of the Legislative Assembly in Puerto Rico

Constitutionally, Puerto Rico is subject to the [plenary
powers](/wiki/Plenary_powers "Plenary powers") of the [United States
Congress](/wiki/United_States_Congress "United States Congress") under the
[territorial clause](/wiki/Territorial_clause "Territorial clause") of
[Article IV of the U.S.
Constitution](/wiki/Article_Four_of_the_United_States_Constitution "Article
Four of the United States Constitution").[263] [Laws enacted at the federal
level in the United States](/wiki/U.S._federal_law "U.S. federal law") apply
to Puerto Rico as well, regardless of its political status. Their residents
[do not have voting representation in the U.S.
Congress](/wiki/Federal_voting_rights_in_Puerto_Rico "Federal voting rights in
Puerto Rico"). Like the different states of the United States, Puerto Rico
lacks "the full sovereignty of an independent nation", for example, the power
to manage its "external relations with other nations", which is held by the
U.S. federal government. The Supreme Court of the United States has indicated
that once the U.S. Constitution has been extended to an area (by Congress or
the courts), its coverage is irrevocable. To hold that the political branches
may switch the Constitution on or off at will would lead to a regime in which
they, not this Court, say "what the law is".[264]

Puerto Ricans "were collectively made [U.S.
citizens](/wiki/U.S._citizenship#Birthright_citizenship "U.S. citizenship")"
in 1917 as a result of the [Jones-Shafroth Act](/wiki/Jones-Shafroth_Act
"Jones-Shafroth Act").[265] U.S. citizens residing in Puerto Rico cannot vote
for the U.S. president, though both major parties, Republican and Democratic,
run primary elections in Puerto Rico to send delegates to vote on a
presidential candidate. Since Puerto Rico is an [unincorporated
territory](/wiki/Unincorporated_territories_of_the_United_States
"Unincorporated territories of the United States") (see above) and not a U.S.
state, the [United States Constitution](/wiki/United_States_Constitution
"United States Constitution") does not fully [enfranchise](/wiki/Enfranchise
"Enfranchise") [U.S. citizens](/wiki/U.S._citizen "U.S. citizen") residing in
Puerto Rico.[253][266]

Only [fundamental rights](/wiki/Fundamental_right "Fundamental right") under
the American federal constitution and adjudications are applied to Puerto
Ricans. Various other U.S. Supreme Court decisions have held which rights
apply in Puerto Rico and which ones do not. Puerto Ricans have a long history
of service in the U.S. Armed Forces and, since 1917, they have been included
in the U.S. [compulsory draft](/wiki/Compulsory_draft "Compulsory draft")
whensoever it has been in effect.

Though the Commonwealth government has its own tax laws, Puerto Ricans are
also required to pay many kinds of U.S. federal taxes, not including the
federal personal income tax for Puerto Rico-sourced income, but only under
certain circumstances.[267][268][269][270][271][272][273][274] In 2009, Puerto
Rico paid $3.742 billion into the [U.S. Treasury](/wiki/U.S._Treasury "U.S.
Treasury").[275] Residents of Puerto Rico pay into Social Security, and are
thus eligible for Social Security benefits upon retirement. They are excluded
from the [Supplemental Security Income](/wiki/Supplemental_Security_Income
"Supplemental Security Income") (SSI), and the island actually receives a
smaller fraction of the [Medicaid](/wiki/Medicaid "Medicaid") funding it would
receive if it were a U.S. state.[276] Also, Medicare providers receive less-
than-full state-like reimbursements for services rendered to beneficiaries in
Puerto Rico, even though the latter paid fully into the system.[277]

While a state may try an individual for the same crime he/she was tried in
federal court, this is not the case in Puerto Rico. Being a U.S. territory,
Puerto Rico's authority to enact a criminal code derives from Congress and not
from local sovereignty as with the states. Thus, such a parallel accusation
would constitute double jeopardy and is constitutionally impermissible.[260]

In 1992, President [George H. W. Bush](/wiki/George_H._W._Bush "George H. W.
Bush") issued a memorandum to heads of executive departments and agencies
establishing the current administrative relationship between the federal
government and the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico. This memorandum directs all
federal departments, agencies, and officials to treat Puerto Rico
administratively as if it were a state, insofar as doing so would not disrupt
federal programs or operations.

Many federal executive branch agencies have significant presence in Puerto
Rico, just as in any state, including the [Federal Bureau of
Investigation](/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation "Federal Bureau of
Investigation"), [Federal Emergency Management
Agency](/wiki/Federal_Emergency_Management_Agency "Federal Emergency
Management Agency"), [Transportation Security
Administration](/wiki/Transportation_Security_Administration "Transportation
Security Administration"), [Social Security
Administration](/wiki/Social_Security_Administration "Social Security
Administration"), and others. While Puerto Rico has its own [Commonwealth
judicial system](/wiki/Judiciary_of_Puerto_Rico "Judiciary of Puerto Rico")
similar to that of a U.S. state, there is also a U.S. federal district court
in Puerto Rico, and Puerto Ricans have served as judges in that Court and in
other federal courts on the U.S. mainland regardless of their residency status
at the time of their appointment. [Sonia Sotomayor](/wiki/Sonia_Sotomayor
"Sonia Sotomayor"), a [New Yorker of Puerto Rican descent](/wiki/Nuyorican
"Nuyorican"), serves as an [Associate Justice](/wiki/Associate_Justice
"Associate Justice") of the [Supreme Court of the United
States](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States "Supreme Court of the United
States"). Puerto Ricans have also been frequently appointed to high-level
federal positions, including serving as [United States
Ambassadors](/wiki/Ambassadors_of_the_United_States "Ambassadors of the United
States") to other nations.

### Foreign and intergovernmental relations

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-
new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg)|

for[verification](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**.

article](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Puerto_Rico&action=edit) by
[adding citations to reliable
sources](/wiki/Help:Introduction_to_referencing_with_Wiki_Markup/1
"Help:Introduction to referencing with Wiki Markup/1"). Unsourced material may

---|---  
  
Main article: [Foreign and intergovernmental relations of Puerto
Rico](/wiki/Foreign_and_intergovernmental_relations_of_Puerto_Rico "Foreign
and intergovernmental relations of Puerto Rico")

Puerto Rico is subject to the [Commerce](/wiki/Commerce_Clause "Commerce
Clause") and [Territorial Clause](/wiki/Territorial_Clause "Territorial
Clause") of the [Constitution of the United
States](/wiki/Constitution_of_the_United_States "Constitution of the United
States") and, therefore, is restricted on how it can engage with other
nations, sharing the opportunities and limitations that state governments have
albeit not being one. As is the case with state governments, regardless, it
has established several [trade agreements](/wiki/Trade_agreement "Trade
agreement") with other nations, particularly with [Hispanic
American](/wiki/Hispanic_America "Hispanic America") countries such as
[Colombia](/wiki/Colombia "Colombia") and [Panamá](/wiki/Panam%C3%A1
"Panamá").[278][279]

It has also established trade promotion offices in many foreign countries, all
Spanish-speaking, and within the United States itself, which now include
[Spain](/wiki/Spain "Spain"), the [Dominican
Republic](/wiki/Dominican_Republic "Dominican Republic"),
[Panama](/wiki/Panama "Panama"), [Colombia](/wiki/Colombia "Colombia"),
[Washington, D.C.](/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington, D.C."), [New York
City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City") and [Florida](/wiki/Florida
"Florida"), and has included in the past offices in [Chile](/wiki/Chile
"Chile"), [Costa Rica](/wiki/Costa_Rica "Costa Rica"), and
[Mexico](/wiki/Mexico "Mexico"). Such agreements require permission from the
[U.S. Department of State](/wiki/U.S._Department_of_State "U.S. Department of
State"); most, are simply allowed by existing laws or trade treaties between
the United States and other nations which supersede trade agreements pursued
by Puerto Rico and different U.S. states.

At the local level, Puerto Rico established by law that the [international
relations](/wiki/International_relations "International relations") which
states and territories are allowed to engage must be handled by the
[Department of State of Puerto Rico](/wiki/Department_of_State_of_Puerto_Rico
"Department of State of Puerto Rico"), an [executive
department](/wiki/Executive_departments_of_the_government_of_Puerto_Rico
"Executive departments of the government of Puerto Rico"), headed by the
[Secretary of State of Puerto Rico](/wiki/Secretary_of_State_of_Puerto_Rico
"Secretary of State of Puerto Rico"), who also serves as the territory's
lieutenant governor. It is also charged to liaise with general
[consuls](/wiki/Consul_\(representative\) "Consul \(representative\)") and
[honorary consuls](/wiki/Honorary_consul "Honorary consul") based in Puerto
Rico. The [Puerto Rico Federal Affairs
Administration](/wiki/Puerto_Rico_Federal_Affairs_Administration "Puerto Rico
Federal Affairs Administration"), along with the [Office of the Resident
Commissioner](/wiki/Resident_Commissioner_of_Puerto_Rico "Resident
Commissioner of Puerto Rico"), manage all its intergovernmental affairs before
entities of or in the United States (including the [federal government of the
United States](/wiki/Federal_government_of_the_United_States "Federal
government of the United States"),
[local](/wiki/Local_government_in_the_United_States "Local government in the
United States") and [state governments of the United
States](/wiki/State_governments_of_the_United_States "State governments of the
United States"), and public or private entities in the United States).

Both entities frequently assist the Department of State of Puerto Rico in
engaging with Washington, D.C.-based ambassadors and federal agencies that
handle Puerto Rico's foreign affairs, such as the U.S. Department of State,
the [Agency for International
Development](/wiki/Agency_for_International_Development "Agency for
International Development"), and others. The current [Secretary of
State](/wiki/Secretary_of_State_of_Puerto_Rico "Secretary of State of Puerto
Rico") is [Víctor Suárez Meléndez](/wiki/V%C3%ADctor_Su%C3%A1rez_Mel%C3%A9ndez
"Víctor Suárez Meléndez") from the [Popular Democratic
Party](/wiki/Popular_Democratic_Party_\(Puerto_Rico\) "Popular Democratic
Party \(Puerto Rico\)") and member of the [Democratic Party of the United
States](/wiki/Democratic_Party_\(United_States\) "Democratic Party \(United
States\)"), while the current [Director of the Puerto Rico Federal Affairs
Administration](/wiki/List_of_Directors_of_the_Puerto_Rico_Federal_Affairs_Administration
"List of Directors of the Puerto Rico Federal Affairs Administration") is
[Juan Eugenio Hernández Mayoral](/wiki/Juan_Eugenio_Hern%C3%A1ndez_Mayoral
"Juan Eugenio Hernández Mayoral") also from the Popular Democratic and member
of the Democratic Party.

The [Resident Commissioner of Puerto
Rico](/wiki/Resident_Commissioner_of_Puerto_Rico "Resident Commissioner of
Puerto Rico"), the [delegate](/wiki/Delegate_\(United_States_Congress\)
"Delegate \(United States Congress\)") elected by Puerto Ricans to represent
them before the federal government, including the [U.S.
Congress](/wiki/U.S._Congress "U.S. Congress"), sits in the [United States
House of Representatives](/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives "United
States House of Representatives"), serves and votes on congressional
committees, and functions in every respect as a legislator except being denied
a vote on the final disposition of legislation on the House floor, also
engages in foreign affairs to the same extent as other members of Congress.
The current Resident Commissioner is [Pedro Pierluisi](/wiki/Pedro_Pierluisi
"Pedro Pierluisi") from the [New Progressive
Party](/wiki/New_Progressive_Party_of_Puerto_Rico "New Progressive Party of
Puerto Rico") and member of the [Democratic Party of the United
States](/wiki/Democratic_Party_\(United_States\) "Democratic Party \(United
States\)").

Many Puerto Ricans have served as United States ambassadors to different
nations and international organizations, such as the [Organization of American
States](/wiki/Organization_of_American_States "Organization of American
States"), mostly but not exclusively in Latin America. For example, Maricarmen
Aponte, a Puerto Rican and now an Acting Assistant Secretary of State,
previously served as U.S. ambassador to [El Salvador](/wiki/El_Salvador "El
Salvador").[280]

### Military

Main article: [Military of Puerto Rico](/wiki/Military_of_Puerto_Rico
"Military of Puerto Rico")

As it is a territory of the United States of America, the defense of Puerto
Rico is provided by the United States as part of the [Treaty of
Paris](/wiki/Treaty_of_Paris_\(1898\) "Treaty of Paris \(1898\)") with the
President of the United States as its [commander-in-chief](/wiki/Commander-in-
chief "Commander-in-chief"). Puerto Rico has its own [Puerto Rico National
Guard](/wiki/Puerto_Rico_National_Guard "Puerto Rico National Guard"), and its
own [state defense force](/wiki/State_defense_force "State defense force"),
the [Puerto Rico State Guard](/wiki/Puerto_Rico_State_Guard "Puerto Rico State
Guard"), which by local law is under the authority of the Puerto Rico National
Guard.

The [commander-in-chief](/wiki/Commander-in-chief "Commander-in-chief") of
both local forces is the [governor of Puerto
Rico](/wiki/Governor_of_Puerto_Rico "Governor of Puerto Rico") who delegates
his authority to the [Puerto Rico Adjutant
General](/wiki/Puerto_Rico_Adjutant_General "Puerto Rico Adjutant General"),
currently [Brigadier General](/wiki/Brigadier_General "Brigadier General")
[Isabelo Rivera](/wiki/Isabelo_Rivera "Isabelo Rivera"). The Adjutant General,
in turn, delegates the authority over the State Guard to another officer but
retains the authority over the Puerto Rico National Guard as a whole.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Federal_lands_in_Puerto_Rico_and_VI.JPG/800px-
Federal_lands_in_Puerto_Rico_and_VI.JPG)](/wiki/File:Federal_lands_in_Puerto_Rico_and_VI.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Federal_lands_in_Puerto_Rico_and_VI.JPG "Enlarge")

U.S. military installations in Puerto Rico (including the United States Virgin
Islands) throughout the 20th century

U.S. military installations in Puerto Rico were part of the [U.S. Atlantic
Command](/wiki/United_States_Atlantic_Command "United States Atlantic
Command") (LANTCOM after 1993 USACOM), which had authority over all U.S.
military operations that took place throughout the Atlantic. Puerto Rico had
been seen as crucial in supporting LANTCOM's mission until 1999, when U.S.
Atlantic Command was renamed and given a new mission as [United States Joint
Forces Command](/wiki/United_States_Joint_Forces_Command "United States Joint
Forces Command"). Puerto Rico is currently under the responsibility of [United
States Northern Command](/wiki/United_States_Northern_Command "United States
Northern Command").

Both the Naval Forces Caribbean (NFC) and the Fleet Air Caribbean (FAIR) were
formerly based at the Roosevelt Roads Naval Station. The NFC had authority
over all U.S. Naval activity in the waters of the Caribbean while FAIR had
authority over all U.S. military flights and air operations over the
Caribbean. With the closing of the Roosevelt Roads and Vieques Island training
facilities, the U.S. Navy has basically exited from Puerto Rico, except for
the ships that steam by, and the only significant military presence in the
island is the U.S. Army at [Ft Buchanan](/wiki/Fort_Buchanan,_Puerto_Rico
"Fort Buchanan, Puerto Rico"), the Puerto Rican Army and Air National Guards,
and the [U.S. Coast Guard](/wiki/U.S._Coast_Guard "U.S. Coast Guard").
Protests over the noise of bombing practice forced the closure of the naval
base. This resulted in a loss of 6,000 jobs and an annual decrease in local
income of $300 million.[281]

A branch of the [U.S. Army National
Guard](/wiki/United_States_Army_National_Guard "United States Army National
Guard") is stationed in Puerto Rico — known as the [Puerto Rico Army National
Guard](/wiki/Puerto_Rico_Army_National_Guard "Puerto Rico Army National
Guard") — which performs missions equivalent to those of the Army National
Guards of the different [states of the United
States](/wiki/States_of_the_United_States "States of the United States"),
including ground defense, disaster relief, and control of civil unrest. The
local National Guard also incorporates a branch of the [U.S. Air National
Guard](/wiki/United_States_Air_National_Guard "United States Air National
Guard") — known as the [Puerto Rico Air National
Guard](/wiki/Puerto_Rico_Air_National_Guard "Puerto Rico Air National Guard")
— which performs missions equivalent to those of the Air National Guards of
each one of the U.S. states.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/USS_Maryland_%28SSBN-738%29_1997.jpg/300px-
USS_Maryland_%28SSBN-738%29_1997.jpg)](/wiki/File:USS_Maryland_\(SSBN-738\)_1997.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:USS_Maryland_\(SSBN-738\)_1997.jpg "Enlarge")

[_Ohio_ -class](/wiki/Ohio-class_submarine "Ohio-class submarine") [ballistic
missile submarine](/wiki/Ballistic_missile_submarine "Ballistic missile
submarine") USS _Maryland_ , [Roosevelt Roads Naval
Station](/wiki/Roosevelt_Roads_Naval_Station "Roosevelt Roads Naval Station"),
1997

At different times in the 20th century, the U.S. had about 25 military or
naval installations in Puerto Rico, some very small ones,[282] as well as
large installations. The largest of these installations were the former
[Roosevelt Roads Naval Station](/wiki/Roosevelt_Roads_Naval_Station "Roosevelt
Roads Naval Station") in [Ceiba](/wiki/Ceiba,_Puerto_Rico "Ceiba, Puerto
Rico"), the Atlantic Fleet Weapons Training Facility (AFWTF) on
[Vieques](/wiki/Vieques "Vieques"), the National Guard training facility at
[Camp Santiago](/wiki/Camp_Santiago "Camp Santiago") in
[Salinas](/wiki/Salinas,_Puerto_Rico "Salinas, Puerto Rico"), [Fort
Allen](/wiki/Fort_Allen,_Puerto_Rico "Fort Allen, Puerto Rico") in [Juana
Diaz](/wiki/Juana_Diaz "Juana Diaz"), the Army's [Fort
Buchanan](/wiki/Fort_Buchanan,_Puerto_Rico "Fort Buchanan, Puerto Rico") in
San Juan, the former U.S. Air Force Ramey Air Force Base in Aguadilla, and the
Puerto Rico Air National Guard at Muñiz Air Force base in [San
Juan](/wiki/San_Juan,_Puerto_Rico "San Juan, Puerto Rico").[283]

The former U.S. Navy facilities at Roosevelt Roads, Vieques, and Sabana Seca
have been deactivated and partially turned over to the local government. Other
than [U.S. Coast Guard](/wiki/U.S._Coast_Guard "U.S. Coast Guard") and Puerto
Rico National Guard facilities, there are only two remaining military
installations in Puerto Rico: the U.S. Army's small Ft. Buchanan (supporting
local veterans and reserve units) and the PRANG (Puerto Rico Air National
Guard) Muñiz Air Base (the C-130 Fleet). In recent years, the [U.S.
Congress](/wiki/U.S._Congress "U.S. Congress") has considered their
deactivations, but these have been opposed by diverse public and private
entities in Puerto Rico – such as retired military who rely on Ft. Buchanan
for the services available there.

Puerto Ricans have participated in many of the military conflicts in which the
United States has been involved. For example, they participated in the
