[American Revolution](/wiki/American_Revolution "American Revolution"), when
volunteers from Puerto Rico, [Cuba](/wiki/Cuba "Cuba"), and
[Mexico](/wiki/Mexico "Mexico") fought the
[British](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Great_Britain "Kingdom of Great Britain") in 1779
under the command of General [Bernardo de
Gálvez](/wiki/Bernardo_de_G%C3%A1lvez "Bernardo de Gálvez") (1746–1786),[284]
and have continued to participate up to the present-day conflicts in
[Iraq](/wiki/Iraq "Iraq") and [Afghanistan](/wiki/Afghanistan
"Afghanistan").[285]

A significant number of Puerto Ricans participate as members and work for the
U.S. Armed Services, largely as [National
Guard](/wiki/National_Guard_of_the_United_States "National Guard of the United
States") members and civilian employees. The size of the overall military-
related community in Puerto Rico is estimated to be 100,000 individuals. This
includes retired personnel.[283] Fort Buchanan has about 4,000 military and
civilian personnel. In addition, approximately 17,000 people are members of
the Puerto Rico Army and Air National Guards, or the U.S. Reserve forces.[286]
Puerto Rican soldiers have served in every U.S. military conflict from [World
War I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I") to the current military engagement
known by the United States and its allies as the [War against
Terrorism](/wiki/War_on_Terror "War on Terror").

The [65th Infantry Regiment](/wiki/65th_Infantry_Regiment "65th Infantry
Regiment"), nicknamed "_The Borinqueneers_ " from the original Taíno name of
the island (Borinquen), is a [Puerto Rican](/wiki/Puerto_Rican_people "Puerto
Rican people") regiment of the [United States Army](/wiki/United_States_Army
"United States Army"). The regiment's motto is _Honor et Fidelitas_ , Latin
for _Honor and Fidelity_. The 65th Infantry Regiment participated in [World
War I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I"), [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II
"World War II"), the [Korean War](/wiki/Korean_War "Korean War"), and the [War
on Terror](/wiki/War_on_Terror "War on Terror") and in 2014 was awarded the
[Congressional Gold Medal](/wiki/Congressional_Gold_Medal "Congressional Gold
Medal"), presented by [President](/wiki/President_of_the_United_States
"President of the United States") [Barack Obama](/wiki/Barack_Obama "Barack
Obama"), for its heroism during the Korean War.

### Administrative divisions

Main article: [Municipalities of Puerto
Rico](/wiki/Municipalities_of_Puerto_Rico "Municipalities of Puerto Rico")

There are no counties, as there are in 48 of the 50 United States. There are
78 [municipalities](/wiki/Municipalities_of_Puerto_Rico "Municipalities of
Puerto Rico"). Municipalities are subdivided into _[barrios](/wiki/Barrio
"Barrio")_ , and those into sectors. Each municipality has a
[mayor](/wiki/Mayor "Mayor") and a municipal legislature elected to four-year
terms.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/USA_Puerto_Rico_labeled.svg/800px-
USA_Puerto_Rico_labeled.svg.png)](/wiki/File:USA_Puerto_Rico_labeled.svg)

[](/wiki/File:USA_Puerto_Rico_labeled.svg "Enlarge")

A map of Puerto Rico showing its municipalities

## Economy

Main articles: [Economy of Puerto Rico](/wiki/Economy_of_Puerto_Rico "Economy
of Puerto Rico") and [Puerto Rico government-debt
crisis](/wiki/Puerto_Rico_government-debt_crisis "Puerto Rico government-debt
crisis")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Puerto-rico-gdp-by-
sector.png/350px-Puerto-rico-gdp-by-sector.png)](/wiki/File:Puerto-rico-gdp-
by-sector.png)

[](/wiki/File:Puerto-rico-gdp-by-sector.png "Enlarge")

Puerto Rico's [gross domestic product](/wiki/Gross_domestic_product "Gross
domestic product") (GDP) by [economic sector](/wiki/Economic_sector "Economic
sector")

The economy of Puerto Rico is classified as a [high income
economy](/wiki/High_income_economy "High income economy") by the [World
Bank](/wiki/World_Bank "World Bank") and as the most competitive economy in
[Latin America](/wiki/Latin_America "Latin America") by the [World Economic
Forum](/wiki/World_Economic_Forum "World Economic Forum") but Puerto Rico
currently has a public debt of $72.204 billion (equivalent to 103% of GNP),
and a government deficit of $2.5 billion.[287][288] According to [World
Bank](/wiki/World_Bank "World Bank"), [gross national
income](/wiki/Gross_national_income "Gross national income") per capita of
Puerto Rico in 2013 is $23,830 (PPP, International Dollars), ranked as 63rd
among all sovereign and dependent territories entities in the world.[289] Its
economy is mainly driven by [manufacturing](/wiki/Manufacturing_in_Puerto_Rico
"Manufacturing in Puerto Rico") (primarily pharmaceuticals, textiles,
petrochemicals and electronics) followed by the service industry (primarily
finance, insurance, [real estate](/wiki/Real_estate_in_Puerto_Rico "Real
estate in Puerto Rico") and [tourism](/wiki/Tourism_in_Puerto_Rico "Tourism in
Puerto Rico")).[n][o] In recent years, the territory has also become a popular
destination for MICE ([meetings, incentives, conferencing,
exhibitions](/wiki/Meetings,_incentives,_conferencing,_exhibitions "Meetings,
incentives, conferencing, exhibitions")), with a modern convention centre
district overlooking the [Port of San Juan](/wiki/Port_of_San_Juan "Port of
San Juan").[291]

The [geography of Puerto Rico](/wiki/Geography_of_Puerto_Rico "Geography of
Puerto Rico") and [its political status](/wiki/Political_status_of_Puerto_Rico
"Political status of Puerto Rico") are both determining factors on its
economic prosperity, primarily due to its relatively small size as an island;
[its lack of natural resources](/wiki/Natural_resource_economics "Natural
resource economics") used to produce [raw materials](/wiki/Raw_material "Raw
material")[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_], and, consequently, its dependence on
[imports](/wiki/Import "Import"); as well as its territorial status with the
United States, which controls its [foreign policy](/wiki/Foreign_policy
"Foreign policy") while exerting trading restrictions, particularly in [its
shipping industry](/wiki/Transportation_in_Puerto_Rico "Transportation in
Puerto Rico").

Puerto Rico experienced a recession from 2006 to 2011, interrupted by 4
quarters of economic growth, and entered into recession again in 2013,
following growing fiscal imbalance and the expiration of the IRS Section 936
corporate incentives that the [U.S. Internal Revenue
Code](/wiki/Internal_Revenue_Code "Internal Revenue Code") had applied to
Puerto Rico. This IRS section was critical to the economy, as it established
[tax exemptions](/wiki/Tax_exemption "Tax exemption") for U.S. corporations
that settled in Puerto Rico, and allowed their insular subsidiaries to send
their earnings to the parent corporation at any time, without paying federal
tax on corporate income. Puerto Rico has surprisingly been able to maintain a
relatively low inflation in the past decade while maintaining a [purchasing
power parity](/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity "Purchasing power parity") per
capita higher than 80% of the rest of the world.[292]

Academically, most of Puerto Rico's economic woes stem from federal
regulations that expired, have been repealed, or no longer apply to Puerto
Rico; its inability to become self-sufficient and self-sustainable throughout
history;[p] its highly politicized public policy which tends to change
[whenever a political party gains
power](/wiki/Political_party_strength_in_Puerto_Rico "Political party strength
in Puerto Rico");[q] as well as [its highly inefficient local
government](/wiki/Government_of_Puerto_Rico "Government of Puerto Rico")[r][s]
which has accrued a [public debt](/wiki/Public_debt_of_Puerto_Rico "Public
debt of Puerto Rico") equal to 68% of its [gross domestic
product](/wiki/Gross_domestic_product "Gross domestic product") throughout
time.[t][u]

In comparison to [the different states of the United States](/wiki/U.S._state
"U.S. state"), Puerto Rico is poorer than Mississippi (the poorest state of
the U.S.) with 41% of its population below the [poverty
line](/wiki/Poverty_threshold "Poverty threshold").[v] When compared to Latin
America, Puerto Rico has the highest GDP per capita in the region. Its main
trading partners are the [United States](/wiki/United_States "United States")
itself, [Ireland](/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland "Republic of Ireland"), and
[Japan](/wiki/Japan "Japan"), with most products coming from [East
Asia](/wiki/East_Asia "East Asia"), mainly from [China](/wiki/China "China"),
[Hong Kong](/wiki/Hong_Kong "Hong Kong"), and [Taiwan](/wiki/Taiwan "Taiwan").
At a global scale, Puerto Rico's dependency on oil for
[transportation](/wiki/Transportation_in_Puerto_Rico "Transportation in Puerto
Rico") and electricity generation, as well as its dependency on food imports
and raw materials, makes Puerto Rico volatile and highly reactive to changes
in [the world economy](/wiki/Global_economy "Global economy") and
[climate](/wiki/Climate "Climate"). Puerto Rico's agricultural sector
represents less than 1% of GNP.[299]

### Heavy debt load

In early 2017, the [Puerto Rican government-debt
crisis](/wiki/Puerto_Rican_government-debt_crisis "Puerto Rican government-
debt crisis") posed serious problems for the government which was saddled with
outstanding bond debt that had climbed to $70 billion at a time with a 45
percent poverty rate and 12.4% unemployment that is more than twice the
mainland U.S. average.[300] The debt had been increasing during a decade long
recession.[29]

The Commonwealth had been defaulting on many debts, including bonds, since
2015. With debt payments due, the Governor was facing the risk of a government
shutdown and failure to fund the managed health care system.[301][302]
"Without action before April, Puerto Rico’s ability to execute contracts for
Fiscal Year 2018 with its managed care organizations will be threatened,
thereby putting at risk beginning July 1, 2017 the health care of up to
900,000 poor U.S. citizens living in Puerto Rico", according to a letter sent
to Congress by the Secretary of the Treasury and the Secretary of Health and
Human Services. They also said that "Congress must enact measures recommended
by both Republicans and Democrats that fix Puerto Rico’s inequitable health
care financing structure and promote sustained economic growth."[302]

Initially, the oversight board created under [PROMESA](/wiki/PROMESA
"PROMESA") called for Puerto Rico's governor [Ricardo
Rosselló](/wiki/Ricardo_Rossell%C3%B3 "Ricardo Rosselló") to deliver a fiscal
turnaround plan by January 28. Just before that deadline, the control board
gave the Commonwealth government until February 28 to present a fiscal plan
(including negotiations with creditors for restructuring debt) to solve the
problems. A moratorium on lawsuits by debtors was extended to May 31.[29] It
is essential for Puerto Rico to reach restructuring deals to avoid a
bankruptcy-like process under [PROMESA](/wiki/PROMESA "PROMESA").[303] An
internal survey conducted by the Puerto Rican Economists Association revealed
that the majority of Puerto Rican economists reject the policy recommendations
of the Board and the Rosselló government, with more than 80% of economists
arguing in favor of auditing the debt.[304]

In early August 2017, the island's financial oversight board (created by
PROMESA) planned to institute two days off without pay per month for
government employees, down from the original plan of four days per month; the
latter had been expected to achieve $218 million in savings. Governor Rossello
rejected this plan as unjustified and unnecessary. Pension reforms were also
discussed including a proposal for a 10% reduction in benefits to begin
addressing the $50 billion in unfunded pension liabilities.[32][305]

### Public finances

Main articles: [Puerto Rico government-debt
crisis](/wiki/Puerto_Rico_government-debt_crisis "Puerto Rico government-debt
crisis"), [Budget of the Government of Puerto
Rico](/wiki/Budget_of_the_Government_of_Puerto_Rico "Budget of the Government
of Puerto Rico"), and [public debt of Puerto
Rico](/wiki/Public_debt_of_Puerto_Rico "Public debt of Puerto Rico")

Puerto Rico has an [operating budget](/wiki/Operating_budget "Operating
budget") of about U.S.$9.8 billion with expenses at about $10.4 billion,
creating a structural deficit of $775 million (about 7.9% of the budget).[306]
The practice of approving budgets with a structural deficit has been done for
18 consecutive years starting in 2000. Throughout those years, including
present time, all budgets contemplated issuing bonds to cover these projected
deficits rather than making structural adjustments. This practice increased
Puerto Rico’s cumulative debt, as the government had already been issuing
bonds [to balance its actual
budget](/wiki/Puerto_Rico_government_budget_balance "Puerto Rico government
budget balance") for four decades since 1973.[w][308]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Budget-of-the-
government-of-puerto-rico-2012-percentage.png/400px-Budget-of-the-government-
of-puerto-rico-2012-percentage.png)](/wiki/File:Budget-of-the-government-of-
puerto-rico-2012-percentage.png)

[](/wiki/File:Budget-of-the-government-of-puerto-rico-2012-percentage.png
"Enlarge")

The 2012 Budget of the Government of Puerto Rico

Projected deficits added substantial burdens to an already indebted nation
which accrued [a public debt](/wiki/Public_debt_of_Puerto_Rico "Public debt of
Puerto Rico") of $71B or about 70% of Puerto Rico's gross domestic product.
This sparked [an ongoing government-debt crisis](/wiki/Puerto_Rico_government-
debt_crisis "Puerto Rico government-debt crisis") after Puerto Rico's general
obligation bonds were downgraded to speculative non-investment grade ("junk
status") by three credit rating agencies. In terms of financial control,
almost 9.6%—or about $1.5 billion—of Puerto Rico's central government budget
expenses for FY2014 is expected to be spent on debt service.[x] Harsher budget
cuts are expected as Puerto Rico must now repay larger chunks of debts in the
following years.[_[needs
update](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items
"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers")_]

For practical reasons the budget is divided into two aspects: a "general
budget" which comprises the assignments funded exclusively by the [Department
of Treasury of Puerto Rico](/wiki/Department_of_Treasury_of_Puerto_Rico
"Department of Treasury of Puerto Rico"), and the "consolidated budget" which
comprises the assignments funded by the general budget, by [Puerto Rico's
government-owned corporations](/wiki/List_of_government-
owned_corporations_of_Puerto_Rico "List of government-owned corporations of
Puerto Rico"), by revenue expected from loans, by the sale of government
bonds, by subsidies extended by the [federal government of the United
States](/wiki/Federal_government_of_the_United_States "Federal government of
the United States"), and by other funds.

Both budgets contrast each other drastically, with the consolidated budget
being usually thrice the size of the general budget; currently $29B and $9.0B
respectively. Almost one out of every four dollars in the consolidated budget
comes from U.S. federal subsidies while government-owned corporations compose
more than 31% of the consolidated budget.

The critical aspects come from the sale of bonds, which comprise 7% of the
consolidated budget – a ratio that increased annually due to the government's
inability to prepare a balanced budget in addition to being incapable of
generating enough income to cover all its expenses. In particular, the
government-owned corporations add a heavy burden to the overall budget and
public debt, as none is self-sufficient. For example, in FY2011 the
government-owned corporations reported aggregated losses of more than $1.3B
with the [Puerto Rico Highways and Transportation
Authority](/wiki/Puerto_Rico_Highways_and_Transportation_Authority "Puerto
Rico Highways and Transportation Authority") (PRHTA) reporting losses of
$409M, the [Puerto Rico Electric Power
Authority](/wiki/Puerto_Rico_Electric_Power_Authority "Puerto Rico Electric
Power Authority") (PREPA; the government monopoly that controls all
electricity on the island) reporting losses of $272M, while the [Puerto Rico
Aqueducts and Sewers
Authority](/wiki/Puerto_Rico_Aqueducts_and_Sewers_Authority "Puerto Rico
Aqueducts and Sewers Authority") (PRASA; the government monopoly that controls
all water utilities on the island) reported losses of $112M.[310]

Losses by government-owned corporations have been defrayed through the
issuance of bonds compounding more than 40% of Puerto Rico's entire public
debt today.[311] Holistically, from FY2000–FY2010 Puerto Rico's debt grew at a
[compound annual growth rate](/wiki/Compound_annual_growth_rate "Compound
annual growth rate") (CAGR) of 9% while GDP remained stagnant.[312] This has
not always provided a long-term solution. In early July 2017 for example, the
PREPA power authority was effectively bankrupt after defaulting in a plan to
restructure $9 billion in bond debt; the agency planned to seek Court
protection.[313]

In terms of protocol, the governor, together with the [Puerto Rico Office of
Management and Budget](/wiki/Puerto_Rico_Office_of_Management_and_Budget
"Puerto Rico Office of Management and Budget") (OGP in Spanish), formulates
the budget he believes is required to operate all government branches for the
ensuing fiscal year. He then submits this formulation as a budget request to
the Puerto Rican legislature before July 1, the date established by law as the
beginning of Puerto Rico's fiscal year. While the constitution establishes
that the request must be submitted "at the beginning of each regular session",
the request is typically submitted during the first week of May as the regular
sessions of the legislature begin in January and it would be impractical to
submit a request so far in advance. Once submitted, the budget is then
approved by the legislature, typically with amendments, through a [joint
resolution](/wiki/Joint_resolution "Joint resolution") and is referred back to
the governor for his approval. The governor then either approves it or vetoes
it. If vetoed the legislature can then either refer it back with amendments
for the governor's approval, or approve it without the governor's consent by
two-thirds of the bodies of each chamber.[314]

Once the budget is approved, the Department of Treasury disburses funds to the
Office of Management and Budget which in turn disburses the funds to the
respective agencies, while the [Puerto Rico Government Development
Bank](/wiki/Puerto_Rico_Government_Development_Bank "Puerto Rico Government
Development Bank") (the government's intergovernmental bank) manages all
related banking affairs including those related to the government-owned
corporations.

### Cost of living

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Map-of-jones-act-
carrier-routes-for-puerto-rico.png/350px-Map-of-jones-act-carrier-routes-for-
puerto-rico.png)](/wiki/File:Map-of-jones-act-carrier-routes-for-puerto-
rico.png)

[](/wiki/File:Map-of-jones-act-carrier-routes-for-puerto-rico.png "Enlarge")

A map of [Jones Act](/wiki/Merchant_Marine_Act_of_1920 "Merchant Marine Act of
1920") carrier routes for Puerto Rico

The cost of living in Puerto Rico is high and has increased over the past
decade.[y][315][316][317][318][319][320][321] San Juan's in particular is
higher than [Atlanta](/wiki/Atlanta "Atlanta"), [Dallas](/wiki/Dallas
"Dallas"), and [Seattle](/wiki/Seattle "Seattle") but lower than
[Boston](/wiki/Boston "Boston"), [Chicago](/wiki/Chicago "Chicago"), and [New
York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City").[322] One factor is housing
prices which are comparable to [Miami](/wiki/Miami "Miami") and [Los
Angeles](/wiki/Los_Angeles "Los Angeles"), although property taxes are
considerably lower than most places in the United States.[z]

Statistics used for cost of living sometimes do not take into account certain
costs, such as the high cost of electricity, which has hovered in the 24¢ to
30¢ range per kilowatt/hour, two to three times the national average,
increased travel costs for longer flights, additional shipping fees, and the
loss of promotional participation opportunities for customers "outside the
continental United States". While some online stores do offer free shipping on
orders to Puerto Rico, many merchants exclude Hawaii, Alaska, Puerto Rico and
other United States territories.

The household median income is stated as $19,350 and the mean income as
$30,463 in the U.S. Census Bureau's 2015 update. The report also indicates
that 45.5% of individuals are below the poverty level.[2] The median home
value in Puerto Rico ranges from U.S.$100,000 to U.S.$214,000, while the
national median home value sits at $119,600.[aa]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Flying_into_San_Juan-
Puerto_Rico.jpg/300px-Flying_into_San_Juan-
Puerto_Rico.jpg)](/wiki/File:Flying_into_San_Juan-Puerto_Rico.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Flying_into_San_Juan-Puerto_Rico.jpg "Enlarge")

Flying into the capital San Juan.

One of the most cited contributors to the high cost of living in Puerto Rico
is the [Merchant Marine Act of 1920](/wiki/Merchant_Marine_Act_of_1920
"Merchant Marine Act of 1920"), also known as the [Jones
Act](/wiki/Merchant_Marine_Act_of_1920 "Merchant Marine Act of 1920"), which
prevents foreign-flagged ships from carrying cargo between two American ports,
a practice known as [cabotage](/wiki/Cabotage "Cabotage").[325] Because of the
Jones Act, foreign ships inbound with goods from
[Central](/wiki/Central_America "Central America") and [South
America](/wiki/South_America "South America"), [Western
Europe](/wiki/Western_Europe "Western Europe"), and [Africa](/wiki/Africa
"Africa") cannot stop in Puerto Rico, offload Puerto Rico-bound goods, load
mainland-bound Puerto Rico-manufactured goods, and continue to U.S. ports.
Instead, they must proceed directly to U.S. ports, where distributors [break
bulk](/wiki/Break_bulk_cargo "Break bulk cargo") and send Puerto Rico-bound
manufactured goods to Puerto Rico across the ocean by U.S.-flagged ships.[325]

The [local government of Puerto Rico](/wiki/Government_of_Puerto_Rico
"Government of Puerto Rico") has requested several times to the [U.S.
Congress](/wiki/U.S._Congress "U.S. Congress") to exclude Puerto Rico from the
Jones Act restrictions without success.[ab] The most recent measure has been
taken by the [17th Legislative Assembly of Puerto
Rico](/wiki/17th_Legislative_Assembly_of_Puerto_Rico "17th Legislative
Assembly of Puerto Rico") through R. Conc. del S. 21.[327][328] These measures
have always received support from all the [major local political
parties](/wiki/Political_party_strength_in_Puerto_Rico "Political party
strength in Puerto Rico").

In 2013 the [Government Accountability
Office](/wiki/Government_Accountability_Office "Government Accountability
Office") published a report which concluded that "repealing or amending the
Jones Act cabotage law might cut Puerto Rico shipping costs" and that
"shippers believed that opening the trade to non-U.S.-flag competition could
lower costs".[ac][ad] However, the same GAO report also found that "[shippers]
doing business in Puerto Rico that GAO contacted reported that the freight
rates are often—although not always—lower for foreign carriers going to and
from Puerto Rico and foreign locations than the rates shippers pay to ship
similar cargo to and from the United States, despite longer distances. Data
were not available to allow us to validate the examples given or verify the
extent to which this difference occurred."[330] Ultimately, the report
concluded that "[the] effects of modifying the application of the Jones Act
for Puerto Rico are highly uncertain" for both Puerto Rico and the United
States, particularly for the [U.S. shipping
industry](/wiki/United_States_Merchant_Marine "United States Merchant Marine")
and the military preparedness of the United States.[329][330]

## Education

Main article: [Education in Puerto Rico](/wiki/Education_in_Puerto_Rico
"Education in Puerto Rico")

The first school in Puerto Rico was the _Escuela de Gramática_ (Grammar
School). It was established by Bishop [Alonso Manso](/wiki/Alonso_Manso
"Alonso Manso") in 1513, in the area where the Cathedral of San Juan was to be
constructed. The school was free of charge and the courses taught were Latin
language, literature, history, science, art, philosophy and theology.[331]

Education in Puerto Rico is divided in three levels—Primary (elementary school
grades 1–6), Secondary (intermediate and high school grades 7–12), and Higher
Level (undergraduate and graduate studies). As of 2002, the literacy rate of
the Puerto Rican population was 94.1%; by gender, it was 93.9% for males and
94.4% for females.[332] According to the 2000 Census, 60.0% of the population
attained a high school degree or higher level of education, and 18.3% has a
bachelor's degree or higher.

Instruction at the primary school level is compulsory between the ages of 5
and 18. As of
2010[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Puerto_Rico&action=edit),
there are 1539 public schools and 806 private schools.[333]

The largest and oldest university system is the public [University of Puerto
Rico](/wiki/University_of_Puerto_Rico "University of Puerto Rico") (UPR) with
11 campuses. The largest private university systems on the island are the
[Sistema Universitario Ana G.
Mendez](/wiki/Sistema_Universitario_Ana_G._Mendez "Sistema Universitario Ana
G. Mendez") which operates the [Universidad del
Turabo](/wiki/University_of_Turabo "University of Turabo"), [Metropolitan
University](/wiki/Metropolitan_University_\(Puerto_Rico\) "Metropolitan
University \(Puerto Rico\)") and [Universidad del
Este](/wiki/Universidad_del_Este "Universidad del Este"). Other private
universities include the multi-campus [Inter American
University](/wiki/Inter_American_University_of_Puerto_Rico "Inter American
University of Puerto Rico"), the [Pontifical Catholic
University](/wiki/Catholic_University_of_Puerto_Rico "Catholic University of
Puerto Rico"), [Universidad Politécnica de Puerto
Rico](/wiki/Polytechnic_University_of_Puerto_Rico "Polytechnic University of
Puerto Rico"), and the [Universidad del Sagrado
Corazón](/wiki/University_of_the_Sacred_Heart_\(Puerto_Rico\) "University of
the Sacred Heart \(Puerto Rico\)"). Puerto Rico has four schools of Medicine
and three ABA-approved Law Schools.

## Public health and safety

As of
2015[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Puerto_Rico&action=edit),
medical care in Puerto Rico had been heavily impacted by emigration of doctors
to the mainland and underfunding of the Medicare and Medicaid programs which
serve 60% of the island's population. Affordable medical insurance under the
[Affordable Care Act](/wiki/Affordable_Care_Act "Affordable Care Act") is not
available in Puerto Rico as, since Puerto Ricans pay no income tax, no
subsidies are available.[334]

The city of [San Juan](/wiki/San_Juan,_Puerto_Rico "San Juan, Puerto Rico")
has a system of [triage](/wiki/Triage "Triage"), hospital, and preventive care
health services. The municipal government sponsors regular health fairs in
different areas of the city focusing on health care for the elderly and the
disabled.

In 2017, there were 69 hospitals in Puerto Rico.[335] There are twenty
hospitals in San Juan, half of which are operated by the government. The
largest hospital is the _Centro Médico de Río Piedras_ (the Río Piedras
Medical Center). Founded in 1956, it is operated by the Medical Services
Administration of the Department of Health of Puerto Rico, and is actually a
network of eight hospitals:

    

  * San Juan Municipal Hospital: This hospital is operated by the San Juan municipal government.
  * Industrial Hospital: This is the hospital for Puerto Rico government employees, whether municipal or Commonwealth government employees. Normally, injured police officers and firefighters are cared for here.
  * San Juan Pediatric Hospital – Also operated by the San Juan municipal government.
  * Pediatric Hospital: Operated by the government of the Commonwealth, this is the main trauma hospital for pediatric cases.
  * Centro Medico Emergency Room: This is the main hospital for trauma cases for Puerto Rico and the Caribbean.
  * _Centro Cardiovascular del Caribe_ (Caribbean Cardiovascular Center): This is the main hospital for open heart surgery in the Caribbean. It features a hotel for the patients' families.
  * Psychiatric Hospital: The main psychiatric hospital in Puerto Rico. Operated by the government of Puerto Rico.
  * Psychiatric Correctional Hospital: It is both a hospital and correctional facility. It is operated jointly by the Puerto Rico Department of Corrections and the Medical Services Administration.

The city of San Juan operates nine other hospitals. Of these, eight are
Diagnostic and Treatment Centers located in communities throughout San Juan.
These nine hospitals are:

    

  * [La Perla](/wiki/La_Perla,_San_Juan,_Puerto_Rico "La Perla, San Juan, Puerto Rico")
  * [Puerta de Tierra](/wiki/Puerta_de_Tierra,_Puerto_Rico "Puerta de Tierra, Puerto Rico")
  * Llorens Torres
  * Puerto Nuevo
  * San José
  * Río Piedras
  * Sabana Llana
  * Hoare
  * Santurce Parada 19

There are also ten private hospitals in San Juan. These are:

    

  * _Hospital Metropilitano_
  * _Hospital Auxilio Mutuo_
  * _Hospital Auxilio Mutuo Expreso_
  * Hospital de Veteranos: The main Veterans hospital in the Caribbean. Operated by the U.S. Veteran Healthcare System.
  * Ashford Presbyterian Hospital
  * Hospital Pavia Hato Rey
  * Hospital Pavia Santurce
  * San Jorge Children's Hospital: The most well known children's hospital in the San Juan Metropolitan Area.
  * Hospital San Gerardo: Located at the Cupey neighborhood, is a small hospital but is also specialized in psychiatry and elderly.
  * Hospital del Maestro (Teachers Hospital): Located in Hato Rey, this hospital is operated by the Puerto Rico Teachers Association.

The city of [Ponce](/wiki/Ponce,_Puerto_Rico "Ponce, Puerto Rico") is served
by several clinics and hospitals. There are four comprehensive care hospitals:
[Hospital Dr. Pila](/wiki/Hospital_Dr._Pila "Hospital Dr. Pila"), Hospital San
Cristobal, [Hospital San Lucas](/wiki/Hospital_San_Lucas "Hospital San
Lucas"),[336] and [Hospital de Damas](/wiki/Hospital_de_Damas "Hospital de
Damas"). In addition, [Hospital Oncológico Andrés
Grillasca](/wiki/Hospital_Oncol%C3%B3gico_Andr%C3%A9s_Grillasca "Hospital
Oncológico Andrés Grillasca") specializes in the treatment of cancer,[337] and
Hospital Siquiátrico specializes in mental disorders.[338] There is also a
[U.S. Department of Veterans
Affairs](/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Veterans_Affairs "United States
Department of Veterans Affairs") Outpatient Clinic that provides health
services to U.S. veterans.[339] The U.S. Veterans Administration will build a
new hospital in the city to satisfy regional needs.[340] Hospital de Damas is
listed in the [U.S. News & World Report](/wiki/U.S._News_%26_World_Report
"U.S. News & World Report") as one of the best hospitals under the U.S.
flag.[341] Ponce has the highest concentration of medical infrastructure per
inhabitant of any municipality in Puerto Rico.

On the island of [Culebra](/wiki/Culebra,_Puerto_Rico "Culebra, Puerto Rico"),
there is a small hospital in the island called _Hospital de Culebra_. It also
offers [pharmacy](/wiki/Pharmacy "Pharmacy") services to residents and
visitors. For emergencies, patients are transported by plane to
[Fajardo](/wiki/Fajardo,_Puerto_Rico "Fajardo, Puerto Rico") on the main
island.[342]

The town of [Caguas](/wiki/Caguas "Caguas") has three hospitals: Hospital Hima
San Pablo, Menonita Caguas Regional Hospital, and the San Juan Bautista
Medical Center.

The town of [Cayey](/wiki/Cayey "Cayey") is served by the _Hospital Menonita
de Cayey_ , and the _Hospital Municipal de Cayey._

_Reforma de Salud de Puerto Rico_ ([Puerto Rico Health
Reform](/wiki/Puerto_Rico_Health_Reform "Puerto Rico Health Reform")) –
locally referred to as _La Reforma_ (The Reform) – is a government-run program
which provides medical and health care services to the indigent and
[impoverished](/wiki/Impoverished "Impoverished"), by means of contracting
private [health insurance](/wiki/Health_insurance "Health insurance")
companies, rather than employing government-owned hospitals and emergency
centers. The Reform is administered by the Puerto Rico Health Insurance
Administration.[343]

### Crime

See also: [Illegal drugs in Puerto Rico](/wiki/Illegal_drugs_in_Puerto_Rico
"Illegal drugs in Puerto Rico")

The overall rate of crime is low in Puerto Rico. The territory has a high
firearm homicide rate. The homicide rate of 19.2 per 100,000 inhabitants was
significantly higher than any U.S. state in 2014.[344][345] Most homicide
victims are gang members and drug traffickers with about 80% of homicides in
Puerto Rico being drug related.[346]

## Culture

Main article: [Culture of Puerto Rico](/wiki/Culture_of_Puerto_Rico "Culture
of Puerto Rico")

Modern Puerto Rican culture is a unique mix of cultural antecedents: including
European (predominantly Spanish, Italian, French, German and Irish), African,
and, more recently, some North American and lots of South Americans. A large
number of Cubans and Dominicans have relocated to the island in the past few
decades.

From the Spanish, Puerto Rico received the Spanish language, the Catholic
religion and the vast majority of their cultural and moral values and
traditions. The United States added English-language influence, the university
system and the adoption of some holidays and practices. On March 12, 1903, the
[University of Puerto Rico](/wiki/University_of_Puerto_Rico "University of
Puerto Rico") was officially founded, branching out from the "Escuela Normal
Industrial", a smaller organization that was founded in Fajardo three years
before.

Much of Puerto Rican culture centers on the influence of music and has been
shaped by other cultures combining with local and traditional rhythms. Early
in the history of Puerto Rican music, the influences of Spanish and African
traditions were most noticeable. The cultural movements across the Caribbean
and North America have played a vital role in the more recent musical
influences which have reached Puerto Rico.[347][348]

The official symbols of Puerto Rico are the _reinita mora_ or [Puerto Rican
spindalis](/wiki/Puerto_Rican_spindalis "Puerto Rican spindalis") (a type of
bird), the [_flor de maga_](/wiki/Thespesia_grandiflora "Thespesia
grandiflora") (a type of flower), and the _ceiba_ or
[kapok](/wiki/Ceiba_pentandra "Ceiba pentandra") (a type of tree). The
unofficial animal and a symbol of Puerto Rican pride is the
[coquí](/wiki/Common_coqu%C3%AD "Common coquí"), a small frog. Other popular
symbols of Puerto Rico are the _[jíbaro](/wiki/J%C3%ADbaro "Jíbaro")_ (the
"countryman"), and the carite.

### Architecture

Main article: [Architecture of Puerto Rico](/wiki/Architecture_of_Puerto_Rico
"Architecture of Puerto Rico")

The architecture of Puerto Rico demonstrates a broad variety of traditions,
styles and national influences accumulated over four centuries of Spanish
rule, and a century of American rule. [Spanish colonial
architecture](/wiki/Spanish_colonial_architecture "Spanish colonial
architecture"), [Ibero-Islamic](/wiki/Islamic_architecture "Islamic
architecture"), [art deco](/wiki/Art_deco "Art deco"), [post-
modern](/wiki/Post-modern_architecture "Post-modern architecture"), and many
other architectural forms are visible throughout the island. From town to
town, there are also many regional distinctions.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/The_Colors_of_Old_San_Juan_%2828488284470%29.jpg/300px-
The_Colors_of_Old_San_Juan_%2828488284470%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:The_Colors_of_Old_San_Juan_\(28488284470\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:The_Colors_of_Old_San_Juan_\(28488284470\).jpg "Enlarge")

[Old San Juan](/wiki/Old_San_Juan "Old San Juan")

Old San Juan is one of the two _barrios_ , in addition to
[Santurce](/wiki/Santurce,_San_Juan,_Puerto_Rico "Santurce, San Juan, Puerto
Rico"), that made up the [municipality](/wiki/Municipality "Municipality") of
San Juan from 1864 to 1951, at which time the former independent municipality
of [Río Piedras](/wiki/R%C3%ADo_Piedras "Río Piedras") was annexed. With its
abundance of shops, historic places, museums, open air cafés, restaurants,
gracious homes, tree-shaded plazas, and its old beauty and architectonical
peculiarity, Old San Juan is a main spot for local and internal tourism. The
district is also characterized by numerous public plazas and churches
including [San José Church](/wiki/San_Jos%C3%A9_Church "San José Church") and
the [Cathedral of San Juan Bautista](/wiki/Cathedral_of_San_Juan_Bautista
"Cathedral of San Juan Bautista"), which contains the tomb of the Spanish
explorer [Juan Ponce de León](/wiki/Juan_Ponce_de_Le%C3%B3n "Juan Ponce de
León"). It also houses the oldest Catholic school for elementary education in
Puerto Rico, the Colegio de Párvulos, built in 1865.

The oldest parts of the district of Old San Juan remain partly enclosed by
massive walls. Several defensive structures and notable [forts](/wiki/Fort
"Fort"), such as the emblematic [Fort San Felipe del
Morro](/wiki/Fort_San_Felipe_del_Morro "Fort San Felipe del Morro"), [Fort San
Cristóbal](/wiki/Castillo_San_Crist%C3%B3bal_\(San_Juan\) "Castillo San
Cristóbal \(San Juan\)"), and [El Palacio de Santa
Catalina](/wiki/El_Palacio_de_Santa_Catalina "El Palacio de Santa Catalina"),
also known as [La Fortaleza](/wiki/La_Fortaleza "La Fortaleza"), acted as the
primary defenses of the settlement which was subjected to numerous attacks.
[La Fortaleza](/wiki/La_Fortaleza "La Fortaleza") continues to serve also as
the executive mansion for the [Governor of Puerto
Rico](/wiki/Governor_of_Puerto_Rico "Governor of Puerto Rico"). Many of the
historic fortifications are part of [San Juan National Historic
Site](/wiki/San_Juan_National_Historic_Site "San Juan National Historic
Site").

During the 1940s, sections of Old San Juan fell into disrepair, and many
renovation plans were suggested. There was even a strong push to develop Old
San Juan as a "small [Manhattan](/wiki/Manhattan "Manhattan")". Strict
remodeling codes were implemented to prevent new constructions from affecting
the common colonial Spanish architectural themes of the old city. When a
project proposal suggested that the old Carmelite Convent in San Juan be
demolished to erect a new hotel, the Institute had the building declared as a
historic building, and then asked that it be converted to a hotel in a renewed
facility. This was what became the _Hotel El Convento_ in Old San Juan. The
paradigm to reconstruct and renovate the old city and revitalize it has been
followed by other cities in the Americas, particularly [Havana](/wiki/Havana
"Havana"), [Lima](/wiki/Lima "Lima") and [Cartagena de
Indias](/wiki/Cartagena_de_Indias "Cartagena de Indias").

Ponce Creole is an [architectural style](/wiki/Architectural_style
"Architectural style") created in [Ponce, Puerto
Rico](/wiki/Ponce,_Puerto_Rico "Ponce, Puerto Rico"), in the late 19th and
early 20th centuries. This style of Puerto Rican buildings is found
predominantly in residential homes in [Ponce](/wiki/Ponce,_Puerto_Rico "Ponce,
Puerto Rico") that developed between 1895 and 1920. Ponce Creole architecture
borrows heavily from the traditions of the French, the Spaniards, and the
Caribbean to create houses that were especially built to withstand the hot and
dry climate of the region, and to take advantage of the sun and sea breezes
characteristic of the southern Puerto Rico's [Caribbean
Sea](/wiki/Caribbean_Sea "Caribbean Sea") coast.[349] It is a blend of wood
and masonry, incorporating architectural elements of other styles, from
[Classical revival](/wiki/Classical_revival "Classical revival") and [Spanish
Revival](/wiki/Spanish_Revival "Spanish Revival") to
[Victorian](/wiki/Victorian_architecture "Victorian architecture").[350]

### Arts

Main article: [Puerto Rican art](/wiki/Puerto_Rican_art "Puerto Rican art")

Puerto Rican art reflects many influences, much from its ethnically diverse
background. A form of [folk art](/wiki/Folk_art "Folk art"), called _santos_
evolved from the Catholic Church's use of [sculptures](/wiki/Sculpture
"Sculpture") to convert indigenous Puerto Ricans to
[Christianity](/wiki/Christianity "Christianity"). _Santos_ depict figures of
saints and other religious icons and are made from native wood, clay, and
stone. After shaping simple, they are often finished by painting them in vivid
colors. _Santos_ vary in size, with the smallest examples around eight inches
tall and the largest about twenty inches tall. Traditionally, santos were seen
as messengers between the earth and Heaven. As such, they occupied a special
place on household [altars](/wiki/Altar "Altar"), where people prayed to them,
asked for help, or tried to summon their protection.

Also popular, _caretas_ or _vejigantes_ are masks worn during
[carnivals](/wiki/Carnival "Carnival"). Similar masks signifying evil spirits
were used in both Spain and Africa, though for different purposes. The Spanish
used their masks to frighten lapsed [Christians](/wiki/Christians
"Christians") into returning to the church, while tribal Africans used them as
protection from the evil spirits they represented. True to their historic
origins Puerto Rican _caretas_ always bear at least several horns and fangs.
While usually constructed of [papier-mâché](/wiki/Papier-m%C3%A2ch%C3%A9
"Papier-mâché"), coconut shells and fine metal screening are sometimes used as
well. Red and black were the typical colors for _caretas_ but their palette
has expanded to include a wide variety of bright hues and patterns.

### Literature

Main article: [Puerto Rican literature](/wiki/Puerto_Rican_literature "Puerto
Rican literature")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Retrato_de_EMdeHostos_por_Francisco_Oller.jpg/170px-
Retrato_de_EMdeHostos_por_Francisco_Oller.jpg)](/wiki/File:Retrato_de_EMdeHostos_por_Francisco_Oller.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Retrato_de_EMdeHostos_por_Francisco_Oller.jpg "Enlarge")

[Eugenio María de Hostos](/wiki/Eugenio_Mar%C3%ADa_de_Hostos "Eugenio María de
Hostos")

Puerto Rican literature evolved from the art of [oral story
telling](/wiki/Oral_literature "Oral literature") to its present-day status.
Written works by the native islanders of Puerto Rico were prohibited and
repressed by the Spanish colonial government. Only those who were commissioned
by the Spanish Crown to document the chronological history of the island were
allowed to write.

[Diego de Torres Vargas](/wiki/Diego_de_Torres_Vargas "Diego de Torres
Vargas") was allowed to circumvent this strict prohibition for three reasons:
he was a priest, he came from a prosperous Spanish family, and his father was
a Sergeant Major in the Spanish Army, who died while defending Puerto Rico
from an invasion by the [Dutch](/wiki/Dutch_people "Dutch people") armada. In
1647, Torres Vargas wrote _Descripción de la Ciudad e Isla de Puerto Rico_
("Description of the Island and City of Puerto Rico"). This historical book
was the first to make a detailed geographic description of the island.[351]

The book described all the fruits and commercial establishments of the time,
mostly centered in the towns of San Juan and Ponce. The book also listed and
described every mine, church, and hospital in the island at the time. The book
contained notices on the State and Capital, plus an extensive and erudite
bibliography. _Descripción de la Ciudad e Isla de Puerto Rico_ was the first
successful attempt at writing a comprehensive history of Puerto Rico.[351]

Some of Puerto Rico's earliest writers were influenced by the teachings of
[Rafael Cordero](/wiki/Rafael_Cordero_\(educator\) "Rafael Cordero
\(educator\)"). Among these was Dr. [Manuel A. Alonso](/wiki/Manuel_A._Alonso
"Manuel A. Alonso"), the first Puerto Rican writer of notable importance. In
1849 he published _El Gíbaro_ , a collection of verses whose main themes were
the poor Puerto Rican country farmer. [Eugenio María de
Hostos](/wiki/Eugenio_Mar%C3%ADa_de_Hostos "Eugenio María de Hostos") wrote
_La peregrinación de Bayoán_ in 1863, which used Bartolomé de las Casas as a
spring board to reflect on Caribbean identity. After this first novel, Hostos
abandoned fiction in favor of the essay which he saw as offering greater
possibilities for inspiring social change.

In the late 19th century, with the arrival of the first printing press and the
founding of the Royal Academy of Belles Letters, Puerto Rican literature began
to flourish. The first writers to express their political views in regard to
Spanish colonial rule of the island were journalists. After the United States
invaded Puerto Rico during the Spanish–American War and the island was ceded
to the Americans as a condition of the Treaty of Paris of 1898, writers and
poets began to express their opposition to the new colonial rule by writing
about patriotic themes.

[Alejandro Tapia y Rivera](/wiki/Alejandro_Tapia_y_Rivera "Alejandro Tapia y
Rivera"), also known as the Father of Puerto Rican Literature, ushered in a
new age of [historiography](/wiki/Historiography "Historiography") with the
publication of _The Historical Library of Puerto Rico_. [Cayetano Coll y
Toste](/wiki/Cayetano_Coll_y_Toste "Cayetano Coll y Toste") was another Puerto
Rican historian and writer. His work _The Indo-Antillano Vocabulary_ is
valuable in understanding the way the [Taínos](/wiki/Ta%C3%ADnos "Taínos")
lived. Dr. [Manuel Zeno Gandía](/wiki/Manuel_Zeno_Gand%C3%ADa "Manuel Zeno
Gandía") in 1894 wrote _La Charca_ and told about the harsh life in the remote
and mountainous coffee regions in Puerto Rico. Dr. [Antonio S.
Pedreira](/wiki/Antonio_S._Pedreira "Antonio S. Pedreira"), described in his
work _Insularismo_ the cultural survival of the Puerto Rican identity after
the American invasion.

With the Puerto Rican diaspora of the 1940s, Puerto Rican literature was
greatly influenced by a phenomenon known as the [Nuyorican
Movement](/wiki/Nuyorican_Movement "Nuyorican Movement"). Puerto Rican
literature continued to flourish and many Puerto Ricans have since
distinguished themselves as authors, journalists, poets, novelists,
playwrights, screenwriters, essayists and have also stood out in other
literary fields. The influence of Puerto Rican literature has transcended the
boundaries of the island to the United States and the rest of the world. Over
the past fifty years, significant writers include [Ed Vega](/wiki/Ed_Vega "Ed
Vega"), [Luis Rafael Sánchez](/wiki/Luis_Rafael_S%C3%A1nchez "Luis Rafael
Sánchez"), [Piri Thomas](/wiki/Piri_Thomas "Piri Thomas"), [Giannina
Braschi](/wiki/Giannina_Braschi "Giannina Braschi"), and [Miguel
Piñero](/wiki/Miguel_Pi%C3%B1ero "Miguel Piñero"). [Esmeralda
Santiago](/wiki/Esmeralda_Santiago "Esmeralda Santiago") has written an
autobiographical trilogy about growing up in modern Puerto Rico as well as an
historical novel, _Conquistadora_ , about life on a sugar plantation during
the mid-19th century.

### Media

Main article: [Media in Puerto Rico](/wiki/Media_in_Puerto_Rico "Media in
Puerto Rico")

The [media](/wiki/Mass_media "Mass media") in Puerto Rico includes local
[radio stations](/wiki/Radio_stations "Radio stations"), [television
stations](/wiki/Television_stations "Television stations") and
[newspapers](/wiki/Newspapers "Newspapers"), the majority of which are
conducted in [Spanish](/wiki/Spanish_language "Spanish language"). There are
also three stations of the [U.S. Armed Forces Radio and Television
Service](/wiki/American_Forces_Network "American Forces Network"). Newspapers
with daily distribution are [El Nuevo Dia](/wiki/El_Nuevo_Dia "El Nuevo Dia"),
[El Vocero](/wiki/El_Vocero "El Vocero") and
[Indice](/w/index.php?title=Indice_\(newspaper\)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Indice
\(newspaper\) \(page does not exist\)"),
[Metro](/w/index.php?title=Metro_\(Puerto_Rico\)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Metro
\(Puerto Rico\) \(page does not exist\)"), and [Primera
Hora](/wiki/Primera_Hora_\(Puerto_Rico\) "Primera Hora \(Puerto Rico\)"). [El
Vocero](/wiki/El_Vocero "El Vocero") is distributed free of charge as well as
[Indice](/w/index.php?title=Indice_\(newspaper\)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Indice
\(newspaper\) \(page does not exist\)") and
[Metro](/w/index.php?title=Metro_\(Puerto_Rico\)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Metro
\(Puerto Rico\) \(page does not exist\)").

Newspapers distributed on a weekly or regional basis include
[Claridad](/wiki/Claridad "Claridad"), [La Perla del
Sur](/wiki/La_Perla_del_Sur "La Perla del Sur"), [La Opinion](/wiki/La_Opinion
"La Opinion"),
[Vision](/w/index.php?title=Vision_\(Puerto_Rico\)&action=edit&redlink=1
"Vision \(Puerto Rico\) \(page does not exist\)"), and [La Estrella del
Norte](/w/index.php?title=La_Estrella_del_Norte&action=edit&redlink=1 "La
Estrella del Norte \(page does not exist\)"), among others. Several television
channels provide local content in the island. These include [WIPR-
TV](/wiki/WIPR-TV "WIPR-TV"),
[Telemundo](/wiki/Telemundo_Puerto_Rico_\(TV_channel\) "Telemundo Puerto Rico
\(TV channel\)"), [Univision Puerto Rico](/wiki/Univision_Puerto_Rico
"Univision Puerto Rico"), [WAPA-TV](/wiki/WAPA-TV "WAPA-TV"), and [WKAQ-
TV](/wiki/WKAQ-TV "WKAQ-TV").

### Music

Main article: [Music of Puerto Rico](/wiki/Music_of_Puerto_Rico "Music of
Puerto Rico")

![File:Bomba-1.ogv](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Bomba-1.ogv/220px
--Bomba-1.ogv.jpg)[Play
media](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/e8/Bomba-1.ogv "Play media")

[](/wiki/File:Bomba-1.ogv "Enlarge")

A dancer performs typical _[bomba](/wiki/Bomba_\(Puerto_Rico\) "Bomba \(Puerto
Rico\)")_ choreography.

The music of Puerto Rico has evolved as a heterogeneous and dynamic product of
diverse cultural resources. The most conspicuous musical sources have been
Spain and West Africa, although many aspects of Puerto Rican music reflect
origins elsewhere in Europe and the Caribbean and, over the last century, from
the U.S. Puerto Rican music culture today comprises a wide and rich variety of
genres, ranging from indigenous genres like
[bomba](/wiki/Bomba_\(Puerto_Rico\) "Bomba \(Puerto Rico\)"),
[plena](/wiki/Plena "Plena"), [aguinaldo](/wiki/Aguinaldo "Aguinaldo"),
[danza](/wiki/Danza "Danza") and [salsa](/wiki/Salsa_music "Salsa music") to
recent hybrids like [reggaeton](/wiki/Reggaeton "Reggaeton").

Puerto Rico has some national instruments, like the
[cuatro](/wiki/Puerto_Rican_cuatro "Puerto Rican cuatro") (Spanish for
"four"). The cuatro is a local instrument that was made by the "Jibaro" or
people from the mountains. Originally, the Cuatro consisted of four steel
strings, hence its name, but currently the Cuatro consists of five double
steel strings. It is easily confused with a guitar, even by locals. When held
upright, from right to left, the strings are G, D, A, E, B.

In the realm of [classical music](/wiki/Classical_music "Classical music"),
the island hosts two main orchestras, the [Orquesta Sinfónica de Puerto
Rico](/wiki/Orquesta_Sinf%C3%B3nica_de_Puerto_Rico "Orquesta Sinfónica de
Puerto Rico") and the Orquesta Filarmónica de Puerto Rico. The [Casals
Festival](/wiki/Casals_Festival "Casals Festival") takes place annually in San
Juan, drawing in classical musicians from around the world.

With respect to [opera](/wiki/Opera "Opera"), the legendary Puerto Rican tenor
[Antonio Paoli](/wiki/Antonio_Paoli "Antonio Paoli") was so celebrated, that
he performed private recitals for [Pope Pius X](/wiki/Pope_Pius_X "Pope Pius
X") and the [Czar Nicholas II of Russia](/wiki/Czar_Nicholas_II_of_Russia
"Czar Nicholas II of Russia"). In 1907, Paoli was the first operatic artist in
world history to record an entire opera – when he participated in a
performance of _[Pagliacci](/wiki/Pagliacci "Pagliacci")_ by [Ruggiero
Leoncavallo](/wiki/Ruggiero_Leoncavallo "Ruggiero Leoncavallo") in Milan,
Italy.

Over the past fifty years, Puerto Rican artists such as Jorge Emmanuelli,
[Yomo Toro](/wiki/Yomo_Toro "Yomo Toro"), [Ramito](/wiki/Ramito "Ramito"),
[Jose Feliciano](/wiki/Jose_Feliciano "Jose Feliciano"), [Bobby
Capo](/wiki/Bobby_Capo "Bobby Capo"), [Rafael Cortijo](/wiki/Rafael_Cortijo
"Rafael Cortijo"), [Ismael Rivera](/wiki/Ismael_Rivera "Ismael Rivera"),
[Chayanne](/wiki/Chayanne "Chayanne"), [Tito Puente](/wiki/Tito_Puente "Tito
Puente"), [Eddie Palmieri](/wiki/Eddie_Palmieri "Eddie Palmieri"), [Ray
Barreto](/wiki/Ray_Barreto "Ray Barreto"), [Dave Valentin](/wiki/Dave_Valentin
"Dave Valentin"), [Omar Rodríguez-López](/wiki/Omar_Rodr%C3%ADguez-L%C3%B3pez
"Omar Rodríguez-López"), [Hector Lavoe](/wiki/Hector_Lavoe "Hector Lavoe"),
[Ricky Martin](/wiki/Ricky_Martin "Ricky Martin"), [Marc
Anthony](/wiki/Marc_Anthony "Marc Anthony") and [Luis Fonsi](/wiki/Luis_Fonsi
"Luis Fonsi") have gained fame internationally.

### Cuisine

Main article: [Puerto Rican cuisine](/wiki/Puerto_Rican_cuisine "Puerto Rican
cuisine")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/e/ef/Cuchifritos.jpg/220px-
Cuchifritos.jpg)](/wiki/File:Cuchifritos.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Cuchifritos.jpg "Enlarge")

_[Cuchifritos](/wiki/Cuchifritos "Cuchifritos")_ (_Carnitas_) in New York

Puerto Rican cuisine has its roots in the cooking traditions and practices of
Europe (Spain), Africa and the native [Taínos](/wiki/Ta%C3%ADno "Taíno"). In
the latter part of the 19th century, the cuisine of Puerto Rico was greatly
influenced by the [United States](/wiki/Cuisine_of_the_United_States "Cuisine
of the United States") in the ingredients used in its preparation. Puerto
Rican cuisine has transcended the boundaries of the island, and can be found
in several countries outside the [archipelago](/wiki/Archipelago
"Archipelago"). Basic ingredients include [grains](/wiki/Grain "Grain") and
[legumes](/wiki/Legume "Legume"), [herbs](/wiki/Herb "Herb") and
[spices](/wiki/Spice "Spice"), starchy tropical [tubers](/wiki/Tuber "Tuber"),
vegetables, meat and poultry, seafood and shellfish, and fruits. Main dishes
include _[mofongo](/wiki/Mofongo "Mofongo")_ , _[arroz con
gandules](/wiki/Arroz_con_gandules "Arroz con gandules")_ ,
_[pasteles](/wiki/Pasteles "Pasteles")_ , _[alcapurrias](/wiki/Alcapurrias
"Alcapurrias")_ and [pig roast](/wiki/Pig_roast "Pig roast") (or lechón).
Beverages include _[maví](/wiki/Mauby "Mauby")_ and _[piña
colada](/wiki/Pi%C3%B1a_colada "Piña colada")_. Desserts include flan, _arroz
con dulce_ (sweet [rice pudding](/wiki/Rice_pudding "Rice pudding")),
_[piraguas](/wiki/Piragua_\(food\) "Piragua \(food\)")_ , _[brazo
gitanos](/wiki/Brazo_gitano "Brazo gitano")_ , _[tembleque](/wiki/Tembleque
"Tembleque")_ , _[polvorones](/wiki/Polvor%C3%B3n "Polvorón")_ , and _[dulce
de leche](/wiki/Dulce_de_leche "Dulce de leche")_.

Locals call their cuisine _**cocina criolla**_. The traditional Puerto Rican
cuisine was well established by the end of the 19th century. By 1848 the first
restaurant, [La Mallorquina](/wiki/La_Mallorquina "La Mallorquina"), opened in
[Old San Juan](/wiki/Old_San_Juan "Old San Juan"). _El Cocinero
Puertorriqueño_ , the island's first cookbook was published in 1849.[352]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Aranitas_tostones.jpg/220px-
Aranitas_tostones.jpg)](/wiki/File:Aranitas_tostones.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Aranitas_tostones.jpg "Enlarge")

Plantain "arañitas" and "tostones rellenos"

From the diet of the [Taíno](/wiki/Ta%C3%ADno "Taíno") people come many
tropical roots and tubers like _[yautía](/wiki/Taro "Taro")_ (taro) and
especially _Yuca_ (cassava), from which thin cracker-like
_[casabe](/wiki/Casabe "Casabe")_ bread is made. Ajicito or cachucha pepper, a
slightly hot habanero pepper, _[recao/culantro](/wiki/Culantro "Culantro")_
(spiny leaf), _[achiote](/wiki/Annato "Annato")_ (annatto),
_[peppers](/wiki/Capsicum "Capsicum")_ , _[ají
caballero](/wiki/Aj%C3%AD_caballero "Ají caballero")_ (the hottest pepper
native to Puerto Rico), peanuts, [guavas](/wiki/Guava "Guava"),
[pineapples](/wiki/Pineapple "Pineapple"), _[jicacos](/wiki/Cocoplum
"Cocoplum")_ (cocoplum), _[quenepas](/wiki/Mamoncillo "Mamoncillo")_
(mamoncillo), _[lerenes](/wiki/Calathea_allouia "Calathea allouia")_ (Guinea
arrowroot), _[calabazas](/wiki/Calabaza "Calabaza")_ (tropical pumpkins), and
_[guanabanas](/wiki/Soursop "Soursop")_ (soursops) are all Taíno foods. The
Taínos also grew varieties of [beans](/wiki/Bean "Bean") and some maize/corn,
but maize was not as dominant in their cooking as it was for the peoples
living on the mainland of [Mesoamerica](/wiki/Mesoamerica "Mesoamerica"). This
is due to the frequent hurricanes that Puerto Rico experiences, which destroy
crops of maize, leaving more safeguarded plants like _conucos_ (hills of
_yuca_ grown together).

Spanish / European influence is also seen in Puerto Rican cuisine. Wheat,
[chickpeas](/wiki/Chickpea "Chickpea") (garbanzos), [capers](/wiki/Caper
"Caper"), [olives](/wiki/Olive "Olive"), [olive oil](/wiki/Olive_oil "Olive
oil"), [black pepper](/wiki/Black_pepper "Black pepper"), onions, garlic,
_cilantrillo_ ([cilantro](/wiki/Cilantro "Cilantro")), [oregano](/wiki/Oregano
"Oregano"), [basil](/wiki/Basil "Basil"), [sugarcane](/wiki/Sugarcane
"Sugarcane"), [citrus](/wiki/Citrus "Citrus") fruit, [eggplant](/wiki/Eggplant
"Eggplant"), [ham](/wiki/Ham "Ham"), [lard](/wiki/Lard "Lard"),
[chicken](/wiki/Chicken_\(food\) "Chicken \(food\)"), beef, pork, and cheese
all came to Borikén (Puerto Rico's native Taino name) from Spain. The
tradition of cooking complex stews and rice dishes in pots such as rice and
beans are also thought to be originally European (much like Italians,
Spaniards, and the British). Early [Dutch](/wiki/Dutch_people "Dutch people"),
French, Italian, and Chinese immigrants influenced not only the culture but
Puerto Rican cooking as well. This great variety of traditions came together
to form La Cocina Criolla.

Coconuts, coffee (brought by the Arabs and Corsos to Yauco from
[Kafa](/wiki/Kaffa_Province,_Ethiopia "Kaffa Province, Ethiopia"), Ethiopia),
[okra](/wiki/Okra "Okra"), [yams](/wiki/Yam_\(vegetable\) "Yam
\(vegetable\)"), [sesame seeds](/wiki/Sesame_seeds "Sesame seeds"), _gandules_
([pigeon peas](/wiki/Pigeon_pea "Pigeon pea") in English) sweet bananas,
plantains, other root vegetables and Guinea hen, all come to Puerto Rico from
Africa.

### Philately

Main article: [Puerto Rico on stamps](/wiki/Puerto_Rico_on_stamps "Puerto Rico
on stamps")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/San_Juan_1971_U.S._stamp.1.jpg/170px-
San_Juan_1971_U.S._stamp.1.jpg)](/wiki/File:San_Juan_1971_U.S._stamp.1.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:San_Juan_1971_U.S._stamp.1.jpg "Enlarge")

San Juan 450th  
1971 issue

Puerto Rico has been commemorated on four U.S. postal stamps and four
personalities have been featured. Insular Territories were commemorated in
1937, the third stamp honored Puerto Rico featuring '[La
Fortaleza](/wiki/La_Fortaleza "La Fortaleza")', the Spanish Governor's
Palace.[353] The first free election for governor of the U.S. colony of Puerto
Rico was honored on April 27, 1949, at San Juan, Puerto Rico. 'Inauguration'
on the 3-cent stamp refers to the election of [Luis Munoz
Marin](/wiki/Luis_Munoz_Marin "Luis Munoz Marin"), the first democratically
elected governor of Puerto Rico.[354] San Juan, Puerto Rico was commemorated
with an 8-cent stamp on its 450th anniversary issued September 12, 1971,
featuring a sentry box from [Castillo San Felipe del
Morro](/wiki/Castillo_San_Felipe_del_Morro "Castillo San Felipe del
Morro").[355] In the "Flags of our nation series" 2008–2012, of the fifty-
five, five territorial flags were featured. Forever stamps included the
[Puerto Rico Flag](/wiki/Flags_of_Puerto_Rico "Flags of Puerto Rico")
illustrated by a bird issued 2011.[356]

Four Puerto Rican personalities have been featured on U.S. postage stamps.
These include [Roberto Clemente](/wiki/Roberto_Clemente "Roberto Clemente") in
1984 as an individual and in the Legends of Baseball series issued in
2000.[357] [Luis Muñoz Marín](/wiki/Luis_Mu%C3%B1oz_Mar%C3%ADn "Luis Muñoz
Marín") in the Great Americans series,[358] on February 18, 1990,[354] [Julia
de Burgos](/wiki/Julia_de_Burgos "Julia de Burgos") in the Literary Arts
series, issued 2010,[359] and [José Ferrer](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Ferrer "José
Ferrer") in the Distinguished American series, issued 2012.[360]

### Sports

Main article: [Sports in Puerto Rico](/wiki/Sports_in_Puerto_Rico "Sports in
Puerto Rico")

[Baseball](/wiki/Baseball "Baseball") was one of the first sports to gain
widespread popularity in Puerto Rico. The [Puerto Rico Baseball
League](/wiki/Puerto_Rico_Baseball_League "Puerto Rico Baseball League")
serves as the only active professional league, operating as a winter league.
No [Major League Baseball](/wiki/Major_League_Baseball "Major League
Baseball") franchise or affiliate plays in Puerto Rico, however, San Juan
hosted the [Montreal Expos](/wiki/Montreal_Expos "Montreal Expos") for several
series in 2003 and 2004 before they moved to Washington, D.C. and became the
[Washington Nationals](/wiki/Washington_Nationals "Washington Nationals").

The [Puerto Rico national baseball
team](/wiki/Puerto_Rico_national_baseball_team "Puerto Rico national baseball
team") has participated in the [World Cup of
Baseball](/wiki/World_Cup_of_Baseball "World Cup of Baseball") winning one
gold (1951), four silver and four bronze medals, the [Caribbean
Series](/wiki/Caribbean_Series "Caribbean Series") (winning fourteen times)
and the [World Baseball Classic](/wiki/World_Baseball_Classic "World Baseball
Classic"). On March 2006, San Juan's [Hiram Bithorn
Stadium](/wiki/Hiram_Bithorn_Stadium "Hiram Bithorn Stadium") hosted the
opening round as well as the second round of the newly formed [World Baseball
Classic](/wiki/World_Baseball_Classic "World Baseball Classic"). Puerto Rican
baseball players include [Hall of Famers](/wiki/Hall_of_Fame "Hall of Fame")
[Roberto Clemente](/wiki/Roberto_Clemente "Roberto Clemente"), [Orlando
Cepeda](/wiki/Orlando_Cepeda "Orlando Cepeda") and [Roberto
Alomar](/wiki/Roberto_Alomar "Roberto Alomar"), enshrined in 1973, 1999, and
2011 respectively.[361][362][363]

[Boxing](/wiki/Boxing "Boxing"), [basketball](/wiki/Basketball "Basketball"),
and [volleyball](/wiki/Volleyball "Volleyball") are considered popular sports
as well. [Wilfredo Gómez](/wiki/Wilfredo_G%C3%B3mez "Wilfredo Gómez") and
[McWilliams Arroyo](/wiki/McWilliams_Arroyo "McWilliams Arroyo") have won
their respective divisions at the [World Amateur Boxing
Championships](/wiki/World_Amateur_Boxing_Championships "World Amateur Boxing
Championships"). Other medalists include [José
Pedraza](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Pedraza_\(boxer\) "José Pedraza \(boxer\)"), who
holds a silver medal, and three boxers who finished in third place, José Luis
Vellón, [Nelson Dieppa](/wiki/Nelson_Dieppa "Nelson Dieppa") and [McJoe
Arroyo](/wiki/McJoe_Arroyo "McJoe Arroyo"). In the professional circuit,
Puerto Rico has the third-most [boxing world
champions](/wiki/List_of_Puerto_Rican_boxing_world_champions "List of Puerto
Rican boxing world champions") and it is the global leader in champions per
capita. These include [Miguel Cotto](/wiki/Miguel_Cotto "Miguel Cotto"),
[Félix Trinidad](/wiki/F%C3%A9lix_Trinidad "Félix Trinidad"), [Wilfred
Benítez](/wiki/Wilfred_Ben%C3%ADtez "Wilfred Benítez") and Gómez among others.

The [Puerto Rico national basketball
team](/wiki/Puerto_Rico_national_basketball_team "Puerto Rico national
basketball team") joined the [International Basketball
Federation](/wiki/International_Basketball_Federation "International
Basketball Federation") in 1957. Since then, it has won more than 30 medals in
international competitions, including gold in three [FIBA Americas
Championships](/wiki/FIBA_Americas_Championship "FIBA Americas Championship")
and the 1994 [Goodwill Games](/wiki/Goodwill_Games "Goodwill Games") August 8,
2004, became a landmark date for the team when it became the first team to
defeat the [United
States](/wiki/United_States_men%27s_national_basketball_team "United States
men's national basketball team") in an Olympic tournament since the
integration of [National Basketball
Association](/wiki/National_Basketball_Association "National Basketball
Association") players. Winning the inaugural game with scores of 92–73 as part
of the [2004 Summer Olympics](/wiki/2004_Summer_Olympics "2004 Summer
Olympics") organized in [Athens](/wiki/Athens "Athens"), Greece.[364]
[Baloncesto Superior Nacional](/wiki/Baloncesto_Superior_Nacional "Baloncesto
Superior Nacional") acts as the top-level professional basketball league in
Puerto Rico, and has experienced success since its beginning in 1930.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Orangestarsultra.jpg/300px-
Orangestarsultra.jpg)](/wiki/File:Orangestarsultra.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Orangestarsultra.jpg "Enlarge")

[Puerto Rico Islanders](/wiki/Puerto_Rico_Islanders "Puerto Rico Islanders")
fans at a soccer game.

[Puerto Rico](/wiki/Puerto_Rico_national_football_team "Puerto Rico national
football team") is also a member of [FIFA](/wiki/FIFA "FIFA") and
[CONCACAF](/wiki/CONCACAF "CONCACAF"). In 2008, the archipelago's first
unified league, the [Puerto Rico Soccer
League](/wiki/Puerto_Rico_Soccer_League "Puerto Rico Soccer League"), was
established.

Other sports include [professional wrestling](/wiki/Professional_wrestling
"Professional wrestling") and [road running](/wiki/Road_running "Road
running"). The [World Wrestling Council](/wiki/World_Wrestling_Council "World
Wrestling Council") and [International Wrestling
Association](/wiki/International_Wrestling_Association_\(Puerto_Rico\)
"International Wrestling Association \(Puerto Rico\)") are the largest
wrestling promotions in the main island. The [World's Best
10K](/wiki/World%27s_Best_10K "World's Best 10K"), held annually in San Juan,
has been ranked among the 20 most competitive races globally. The "Puerto Rico
All Stars" team, which has won twelve world championships in unicycle
basketball.[365]

Organized [Streetball](/wiki/Streetball "Streetball") has gathered some
exposition, with teams like "Puerto Rico Street Ball" competing against
established organizations including the [Capitanes de
Arecibo](/wiki/Arecibo_Captains "Arecibo Captains") and [AND1](/wiki/AND1
"AND1")'s [Mixtape Tour Team](/wiki/AND1_Mixtape_Tour "AND1 Mixtape Tour").
Six years after the first visit, AND1 returned as part of their renamed Live
Tour, losing to the Puerto Rico Streetballers.[366] Consequently,
practitioners of this style have earned participation in international teams,
including [Orlando "El Gato" Meléndez](/wiki/Orlando_Melendez "Orlando
Melendez"), who became the first Puerto Rican born athlete to play for the
[Harlem Globetrotters](/wiki/Harlem_Globetrotters "Harlem
Globetrotters").[367] [Orlando Antigua](/wiki/Orlando_Antigua "Orlando
Antigua"), whose mother is Puerto Rican, in 1995 became the first Hispanic and
the first non-black in 52 years to play for the Harlem Globetrotters.[368]

Puerto Rico has representation in all international competitions including the
[Summer](/wiki/Summer_Olympics "Summer Olympics") and [Winter
Olympics](/wiki/Winter_Olympics "Winter Olympics"), the [Pan American
Games](/wiki/Pan_American_Games "Pan American Games"), the [Caribbean World
Series](/wiki/Caribbean_World_Series "Caribbean World Series"), and the
[Central American and Caribbean
Games](/wiki/Central_American_and_Caribbean_Games "Central American and
Caribbean Games"). Puerto Rico hosted the Pan Am Games in 1979 (officially in
San Juan), and The [Central American and Caribbean
Games](/wiki/Central_American_and_Caribbean_Games "Central American and
Caribbean Games") were hosted in
[1993](/wiki/1993_Central_American_and_Caribbean_Games "1993 Central American
and Caribbean Games") in [Ponce](/wiki/Ponce,_Puerto_Rico "Ponce, Puerto
Rico") and in [2010](/wiki/2010_Central_American_and_Caribbean_Games "2010
Central American and Caribbean Games") in [Mayagüez](/wiki/Mayag%C3%BCez
"Mayagüez").

Puerto Rican athletes have won nine medals in Olympic competition (one gold,
two silver, six bronze), the first one in 1948 by boxer [Juan Evangelista
Venegas](/wiki/Juan_Evangelista_Venegas "Juan Evangelista Venegas"). [Monica
Puig](/wiki/Monica_Puig "Monica Puig") won the first gold medal for Puerto
Rico in the Olympic Games by winning the [Women's Tennis singles title in Rio
2016](/wiki/Tennis_at_the_2016_Summer_Olympics#Medal_events "Tennis at the
2016 Summer Olympics").[369][370]

## Infrastructure

Main articles: [Transportation in Puerto
Rico](/wiki/Transportation_in_Puerto_Rico "Transportation in Puerto Rico"),
[Communications in Puerto Rico](/wiki/Communications_in_Puerto_Rico
"Communications in Puerto Rico"), [Puerto Rico Electric Power
Authority](/wiki/Puerto_Rico_Electric_Power_Authority "Puerto Rico Electric
Power Authority"), and [Puerto Rico Aqueducts and Sewers
Authority](/wiki/Puerto_Rico_Aqueducts_and_Sewers_Authority "Puerto Rico
Aqueducts and Sewers Authority")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Puerto_Rico_Interstates.svg/350px-
Puerto_Rico_Interstates.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Puerto_Rico_Interstates.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Puerto_Rico_Interstates.svg "Enlarge")

[Puerto Rico interstate highways](/wiki/List_of_highways_in_Puerto_Rico "List
of highways in Puerto Rico")

Cities and towns in Puerto Rico are interconnected by a system of roads,
[freeways](/wiki/Freeway "Freeway"), [expressways](/wiki/Limited-access_road
"Limited-access road"), and [highways](/wiki/Highway "Highway") maintained by
the Highways and Transportation Authority under the jurisdiction of the U.S.
Department of Transportation, and patrolled by the [Puerto Rico Police
Department](/wiki/Puerto_Rico_Police_Department "Puerto Rico Police
Department"). The island's [metropolitan area](/wiki/Metropolitan_area
"Metropolitan area") is served by a [public bus transit
system](/wiki/Autoridad_Metropolitana_de_Autobuses "Autoridad Metropolitana de
Autobuses") and a [metro system](/wiki/Rapid_transit "Rapid transit") called
_[Tren Urbano](/wiki/Tren_Urbano "Tren Urbano")_ (in English: Urban Train).
Other forms of public transportation include seaborne ferries (that serve
Puerto Rico's archipelago) as well as _Carros Públicos_ ([private mini
buses](/wiki/Share_taxi "Share taxi")).

Puerto Rico has three [international airports](/wiki/International_airport
"International airport"), the [Luis Muñoz Marín International
Airport](/wiki/Luis_Mu%C3%B1oz_Mar%C3%ADn_International_Airport "Luis Muñoz
Marín International Airport") in [Carolina](/wiki/Carolina,_Puerto_Rico
"Carolina, Puerto Rico"), [Mercedita Airport](/wiki/Mercedita_Airport
"Mercedita Airport") in Ponce, and the [Rafael Hernández
Airport](/wiki/Rafael_Hern%C3%A1ndez_Airport "Rafael Hernández Airport") in
Aguadilla, and 27 local airports. The Luis Muñoz Marín International Airport
is the largest aerial transportation hub in the Caribbean.[371]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Tren_Urbano_in_Bayam%C3%B3n_%28Puerto_Rico%29.jpg/300px-
Tren_Urbano_in_Bayam%C3%B3n_%28Puerto_Rico%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tren_Urbano_in_Bayam%C3%B3n_\(Puerto_Rico\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Tren_Urbano_in_Bayam%C3%B3n_\(Puerto_Rico\).jpg "Enlarge")

The [Tren Urbano](/wiki/Tren_Urbano "Tren Urbano") system at Bayamón Station

Puerto Rico has nine [ports](/wiki/Port "Port") in different cities across the
main island. The [San Juan Port](/wiki/San_Juan_Port "San Juan Port") is the
largest in Puerto Rico, and the busiest port in the Caribbean and the 10th
busiest in the United States in terms of commercial activity and cargo
movement, respectively.[371] The second largest port is the [Port of the
Americas](/wiki/Port_of_the_Americas "Port of the Americas") in Ponce,
currently under expansion to increase cargo capacity to 1.5 million twenty-
foot containers ([TEUs](/wiki/Twenty-foot_equivalent_unit "Twenty-foot
equivalent unit")) per year.[372]

The **Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority** (**PREPA**)—Spanish: _Autoridad
de Energía Eléctrica_ (**AEE**)—is an [electric power
company](/wiki/Electric_power_company "Electric power company") and the
[government-owned corporation of Puerto Rico](/wiki/List_of_government-
owned_corporations_of_Puerto_Rico "List of government-owned corporations of
Puerto Rico") responsible for [electricity
generation](/wiki/Electricity_generation "Electricity generation"), [power
transmission](/wiki/Electric_power_transmission "Electric power
transmission"), and [power distribution](/wiki/Electric_power_distribution
"Electric power distribution") in Puerto Rico.[373] PREPA is the only entity
authorized to conduct such business in Puerto Rico, effectively making it a
[government monopoly](/wiki/Government_monopoly "Government monopoly"). The
Authority is ruled by a Governing Board appointed by the Governor with the
[advice and consent](/wiki/Advice_and_consent "Advice and consent") of the
[Senate of Puerto Rico](/wiki/Senate_of_Puerto_Rico "Senate of Puerto Rico"),
and is run by an Executive Director.

Telecommunications in Puerto Rico includes radio, television, fixed and mobile
telephones, and the Internet. Broadcasting in Puerto Rico is regulated by the
[U.S. Federal Communications
Commission](/wiki/Federal_Communications_Commission "Federal Communications
Commission") (FCC).[374] As of
2007[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Puerto_Rico&action=edit),
there were 30 TV stations, 125 radio stations and roughly 1 million TV sets on
the island. Cable TV subscription services are available and the [U.S. Armed
Forces Radio and Television Service](/wiki/American_Forces_Network "American
Forces Network") also broadcast on the island.[375]

Patricia Gherovici states that both "Porto Rico" and "Puerto Rico" were used interchangeably in the news media and documentation before, during, and after the U.S. conquest of the island in 1898. The "Porto" spelling, for instance, was used in the [Treaty of Paris](/wiki/Treaty_of_Paris_\(1898\) "Treaty of Paris \(1898\)"), but "Puerto" was used by _[The New York Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York Times")_ that same year. Nancy Morris clarifies that "a curious oversight in the drafting of the [Foraker Act](/wiki/Foraker_Act "Foraker Act") caused the name of the island to be officially misspelled".[16] However, Gervasio Luis Garcia traces the Anglicized spelling to a _[National Geographic](/wiki/National_Geographic_\(magazine\) "National Geographic \(magazine\)")_ article from 1899, after which the spelling was kept by many agencies and entities because of the ethnic and linguistic pride of the English-speaking citizens of the American mainland.[17]

"With my vote, I make the initial request to the Federal Government to begin the process of the decolonization through: (1) Free Association: Puerto Rico should adopt a status outside of the Territory Clause of the Constitution of the United States that recognizes the sovereignty of the People of Puerto Rico. The Free Association would be based on a free and voluntary political association, the specific terms of which shall be agreed upon between the United States and Puerto Rico as sovereign nations. Such agreement would provide the scope of the jurisdictional powers that the People of Puerto Rico agree to confer to the United States and retain all other jurisdictional powers and authorities. Under this option the American citizenship would be subject to negotiation with the United States Government; (2) Proclamation of Independence, I demand that the United States Government, in the exercise of its power to dispose of territory, recognize the national sovereignty of Puerto Rico as a completely independent nation and that the United States Congress enact the necessary legislation to initiate the negotiation and transition to the independent nation of Puerto Rico. My vote for Independence also represents my claim to the rights, duties, powers, and prerogatives of independent and democratic republics, my support of Puerto Rican citizenship, and a "Treaty of Friendship and Cooperation" between Puerto Rico and the United States after the transition process"
